content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								In Plague Inc: Evolved, Your goal is to wipe out the human race with a type of epidemic. The game pretty much speaks for itself. Though the game sometime feels like it is designed for smartphones, it is very fun nonetheless.NO SPOILERS AHEAD.Pros:The Idea of Plague Inc is very unique and the concept is very nice.The Gameplay is fun and addictive.The Variety between the types of plagues is good.The Zombie and Planet of the Apes Plagues are a ton of fun to play with.The Atmosphere at the end of the game is very chilling. As the last humans are dying, everything on Earth stops which can give you such an erie feeling.The Steam Workshop makes this game 10 times better. User Created plagues with custom timelines and traits are very awesome.Mixed Feelings:I don't like clicking on my screen every couple of seconds to catch the bubbles. This clearly is a mobile mechanic in which you need to keep clicking on your screen. When you level up, eventually there is a gene which automatically pops the bubbles for you which a must have.Cons:The Game does get repetitve after you figure out the formula for the game which doesn't take that long.Many major countries are missing from the map.Final Verdict:Overall, Plague Inc: Evolved is a very nice game. Though it does get repetitve after a while, there is plenty of fun to be had playing this game.I give Plague Inc. Evolved an 8/10

												If you are into these kind of games, interested in microbiology, viruses or diseases - this game is totally for you. The game is clearly something unique and interesting. You can develop your own strategies, which you actually need to do for each disease type. Bacteria and viruses I find are very similiar to what they are in real life - so for example viruses are mutating very quickly which is actually true based off of real life studies. I highly recommend the game for the unique idea, good gameplay, low hardware requirements and of course the hyper-realistic world. I hope the game will get better and better as I did find few bugs or errors with the workshop maps which could be caused due to the Scenario maker and not the author him/herself. I give the game a solid 9/10, would recommend.PS: I did play the game on my friend's account for a long time until I could actually buy it. I say that due to the low amount of time playing (only 30min) on this account :).Best regards, Wolfie.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								NOTE: THIS REVIEW IS NOT MY FINAL THOUGHTS OF THE GAME. IF MY OPINION CHANGES DRASTICALLY OR WHENEVER THE GAME IS RELEASED FROM EARLY ACCESS, I WILL REWRITE THIS REVIEW.Do you or have you ever despised humanity? Do you like video games but you're tired of the same old shoot em ups? Do you want something (fairly) new and unique? Well, my friend, this is the right game for you!Create a disease from a variety of disease types (which you have to unlock... fun), select special traits for your disease (also unlocked... more fun), select your difficulty, and infect Patient Zero. You then choose some skills to evolve your plague to make it more lethal, easier to infect others, or resist outside forces (i.e. temperature and drugs). Unfortunately the governments of the countries aren't very keen on the idea of you eliminating the human race, so they'll shut borders, airports and harbors and try to cure your disease, so you'll have to race against the clock to infect the world and evolve enough lethal symptoms to kill the world. Rinse and repeat.The gameplay is fun, there is a bit of strategy on choosing which country to infect, whether you want to be able to infect by air or water first or if you want to invest some points to get bonus infectivity in colder countries. More strategy comes when you get traits for your disease, since they add bonuses to infectivity, extra DNA points, and a couple more nifty abilities. Each disease has some varying traits, like virus evolving frequently, biodisease being so deadly you have to suppress the lethality, nano-virus being built in with a kill switch that you must race against, and there are much more. It's worth it to unlock the diseases, since some of the cooler ones like Neurax Worm (mindcontrol) and Necroa Virus (zombies) are unlocked a bit later and it's always fun to mess around with those. There are also random events that happen that will affect the game, making each experience different.The display looks nice and it's easy enough to see what's going on. There's a cool little body chart that shows you where in the human body your disease affects. You can see what's going on in all countries, how they're combating your plague, how their cure research is coming along, and if the government is still stable there or if it's falling apart.There are also scenarios where you mess around with stuff, mostly stuff like little to none plane transmission, a mirror version of Earth where all of the countries characteristics are reversed, a virus that's DNA is damaged, affecting its transmission, and some more. Steam Workshop also makes an appearance, letting you create your own scenario. The communuty for this game is pretty large and I can see multiplayer being popular when the dev releases it.There are some problems I had with the game, most of them small however. Mostly minor stuff like Portugal being part of Spain, Alaska being part of Canada (to be fair, the dev makes fun of this in an event so I dont care about that :P), Hawaii being nowhere to be seen yet, minor stuff like that. I can see this game becoming a bit repetetive, but it hasn't become that for me yet. One thing I would like to see, though, are different... I guess maps, you'd call them. Stuff like the continental USA with all of the states instead of the whole world, the providences of Canada, a map where the melting of the ice caps has flooded the world, stuff like that. That would make the game more replayable.Regardless of any criticisms I may have, Plague Inc Evolved is a breath of fresh air with plenty to offer and more to come. 9/10. Never has a game made me hate a country for no good reason like this one has. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Greenland... Anyway, get this game now. It's worth it even at the full $15 or your regional equivelant. Just know that this is an Early Access game, so the game isn't complete yet. However the dev updates frequently, so it could be coming out of Early Access soon. Either way, though, it's worth getting. So get it. NOW!

Early Access Review
								Simply put, I love this game. I was a huge fan of the Pandemic series (and still possess a hatred for Madegascar because of Pandemic III) so when I found Plague Inc on iOS i was very excited, and now to have it on my laptop, well, my free time is totally swallowed up. Plague Inc is simple to play but does require a good amount of strategy to master; that is part of it's charm. There is a huge amount of replayability either through trying out harder difficulties, changing which genes you select at the start or what syptoms you use to wipe out humanity quickly. Being able to name my disease has always been one of the things I've loved about Pandemic, and now Plague Inc. Some of the pop ups can be hilarious as a result, "♥♥♥♥♥♥ begins to spread" still being on the top of my favourites list...I'm really looking forward to the multiplayer update that is coming in the future. I bought the game for my girl too, and I want to kick her♥♥♥♥♥I'm yet to try the content creator but, like the rest of Plague Inc, I am sure it'll be awesome. Yes, money well spent. No doubt I will be playing Plague Inc for a long time to come.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												TLTR: It was fun for about 2 hours. Can't really give it a negative even tho it's not very positive.Cool concept and kept me entertained for a couple of hours. After that it just gets repetitive (bacteria, viruses, prions - it's all the same with different names in this game). It's sort of fine as I didn't expect a high-quality game, and I don't feel right giving it a negative just because it's not comprehensive. I was dissapointed by the lack or representation of basic real-life understanding of diseases. Incubation period and the human immune-system for instance does not play a part in this game at all. It was a huge letdown that I came away from this game having learned absolutely nothing about real-life diseases whatsoever.In a nutshell you get some currency with which to buy disease-symptoms and method of infection, and then you monitor how that plays out in a sort of world-sim. It was entertaining until I realized that was all there was.I wouldn't have bought this game knowing what it is, but I can't really give it a negative either. Ah well.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
												The novelty of this game has been slightly tainted, in my opinion, due to having played some 100 hours in class since its Android release.Nevertheless, it's a pretty solid port - you could say it's close to a different game because of all the new features, like Scenario Editor and Co-op/VS Multiplayer. All of them are really nice additions that (with the exception of VS Multiplayer, arguably) help boost the game's longevity, the same way new disease types have done for the mobile version. For the most part, you're gonna be staring at one of three screens: the map screen (showing the disease spread), the disease screen (where you can purchase traits with accumulated DNA), and the world information screen (showing the measures being taken against your disease as well as progress towards human extinction). Anything you can think of is shown, even as graphs detailing your statistical growth, the percentage of population infected and dead, and the cure research conducted and needed.A little thing that's making it more enjoyable to play through is just reading through the symptoms and trying to imagine what unholy suffering I'm causing to the humans, slowly appearing on the map as darkening red dots that stop shuffling about as they poop out their organs. Talk about being morbid and sadistic.The price tag may put you off, especially if you've played the original mobile versions and/or find the additions potentially unnecessary. Just to be sure, grab it on a sale, and let your inner mad scientist free. A million is a statistic after all. Or perhaps 7 billion even.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2015
												Great fun game. A massive improvement over the mobile game, and I've never once experienced a bug or problem, considering it's in early access.The game is challenging yet enjoyable, and the plague types are not all the same which I sometimes found with the mobile game. The steam workshop is an amazing idea, you can download other people's disease types, or upload your own to the workshop.The scenario creator (where you make your own disease type) is very good, easy to use and has guides if you're not sure. It's easy to place your scenario on the workshop too! I've got a fair amount of hours on this game, although about 11 of these are trying to complete the Necroa Virus... it's not easy ;) And a multiplayer mode is also in development!All in all, I'd give it a 9.5 / 10.Update 17th June: The Multiplayer mode has been out for a little while now so I thought I'd update the review to reflect on the new mode.I love 1vs1 Mode, which allows you to challenge your friends to see who can destroy the world first! Another thing to add is the new mechanic that is included in the multiplayer mode. They added new abilities which allow your disease to continue to infect the world while the authorities see your opponent as the priority, so your cure status will increase much slower. There is also abilities which prevent your infected people from being infected with your opponents disease, which makes it much harder for them to finish. I've not really played much of the co-op mode in Multiplayer yet, so I can't comment on what I think of it, although I'm going to assume I'll love it :) After the release of the game (leaving early access), my final judgement is still  9.5 / 10.

Early Access Review
								Do you hate people? Do you want to rid the planet of all life? Are you a microbiologist with Ph.D in virology? Well, look no further, you have found the ultimate entertainment product for the budding misanthropist. Now you have a chance to design your very own microscopic killingmachine, tailored to fit your deepest, darkest, most murderous desire! Kill the world's population with many different strains of many different types of nasty bugs, from fungi to bio weapons to all out nuclear warfare! Disease not spreading fast enough? Evolve it to spread faster. Cure imminent? Evolve it to become more resistant. Not lethal enough? Make the thing as lethal as a .357 magnum to the face! All in all, you will enjoy this...

content:
Posted: March 5
												Plague Inc: Evolved is in my opinion the Best pandemic simulation game out right now.  The goal is to annihilate every human on the planet; all 7.3 billion.  Your 1 of 9 different possible  infections used to carry out the goal; from Bacteria to the Zombie virus Necroa each with a different game play strategy weaved in the simulator.Using special abilities, symptoms and Transmissions to critique the plague while avoiding the the cure.  This is a dark morbid game but you can’t help appreciate the complex strategy and intensity that Plague  Evolved presents you.  I’ve completed the original Plague Inc on my TV box and cell phone now I’m having a hard time stopping again with the new Evolved edition on Steam.Although balancing your plague’s strategy, severity and effectiveness is fun and very addictive, it does have 1 draw back.   Too much time is spent passively waiting around for DNA points to accrue or for your disease to fully infect a territory, even with a fast forward button.  However; all in all I give this game 8.5 out of 10 stars...

content:
Posted: June 5, 2016
												Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!This is a Calm strategy simulation game.Interface/Menu/SettingsThere is mouse sensitivity.The Master volume has a slidebar that shows up in %The Sound volume has a slidebar that shows up in %The Music Volume has a slidebar that shows up in %There are many resolution sizes.You can play this game in fullscreen mode or windowed mode.You are able to change your controls on the keyboard.There are many different languages.There is Steamworkshop and you can create your own scenario.About the game.You are choosing a disease/Virus and your mission is to infect all people and eventually kill them. You are able to name your own Virus. You start off by picking a country, From there you will have to make a nice infection. You can choose to spread the infection with birds, Rats, lifestocks and other things. Your Virus will be able to evolve (Over time by itself) and become stronger. Getting  more deadlier and even protection to yourself. You have to click on the bubbles that will show up (If u want), to gain some more virus points. Which you will be able to spend to make ur virus more deadlier. The stronger your virus, The faster you will be noticed and countries will fight back by developing a cure. You can sell virus evolutions. It's pretty useful if they are useless and wont have any affect anymore. However you will only get a little bit of Virus points back in return.  DESTROY THE HUMANITY!You can name your own virus.Games are short but alot of fun!Addictive.There are alot of different game modes.There is a Tutorial.Music is alright.Graphics is alright.You can fast forward and pause.Steamworkshop.You can save and load game.No fast country information (To see if they are a hot climate or cold, on the mobile its a simple tap and you know it).MULTIPLAYER.There are 2 different modes in the multiplayer mode. There is Versus and Co-op Mode. There is a a small tutorial about the multiplayer, they are explaining the Co-op and Versus mode there. You can play online or playing with 1 friend. The servers are NOT IP BASED. They are all dedicated. There is also a different "unlocking system" The unlock system is only for the multiplayer, It's the same as single player, So that means single player and multiplayer have both different progress. If you unlock upgrades in single player 5 times, These will NOT be unlocked for multiplayer. You can only unlock all multiplayer upgrades in the multiplayer mode. There is a level difficulty and you can choose a disease name. - Pausing and speeding up will send a request to the other player. He needs to accept this if you wish to make it happen. Finding Online matches will NOT take too long.  I will explain a little bit about these 2 modes. In Versus mode: Your goal is to infect the entire world, You do not need to kill everything in order to win. But you can win by killing off the opponents disease hosts or if his disease is cured. The DNA Bubbles will give you points, If you are the first one that will click the bubble you will receive extra bonus of DNA. Killing people will give you extra bonus DNA aswell.In Co-op Mode: You both need to infect the world and then kill them off, (Same rules as in single player) However the enemy/Humans are far more difficult then they are in single player. You will receive bonus DNA if both diseases has infected the same country. If one of the players has lost and their disease has been fully cured. You can help your team mate by sending out "Activate abilities". You can still get points and help him upgrading and evolving his disease. You can also click on the Bubbles to receive DNA.Other things.You are able to play this game for free on the mobile playstore. But its a bit buggy sometimes. I do suggest to try this game for free on the mobile store before you are going to buy it on steam. Just to know how the game is. See it as a Demo.-------------------I Give this game a 8/10

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												This is a morbidly charming game that appears simultaneously mobile-esque simple and simulation-level complex. Fortunately, Plague Inc meets somewhere in the middle.You'll find yourself balancing competing variables: how fast can I infect everyone without raising the world's alarm so that they don't create a cure in time, how deadly should I be (heaven forbid you kill people faster than you can infect them... at least at first), or how exactly do you infect Greenland, use your DNA points, and so on. There is a surprising number of concepts to juggle for such a simple game. On top of that, the different types of plagues (bacteria, virus, fungi, etc.) all play differently and there are random events that keep you on your toes so that games aren't rinse, wash, repeat.That isn't to say that there isn't a rythm to the game (at least on Normal difficulty--I'm no genius and I've won 4 of my 6 games so far) or that certain strategies seem to work better.There are some mobile-esque quibbles that might cause an aneurism if you're a diehard PC master race proponent. There are clickable bubbles to get points, for example.For all the apparent replayability, a multiplayer mode I haven't even touched, and a fascinating strategy game that ends in human extinction all for a fairly low price, this game is worth it.

number of helpful: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 23
												The game is great, and I gladly recommend it. The only bad thing I can say about it is...well, Greenland.At first, I thought the idea of Greenland, the country with the lowest population in the game, being hard to infect was an exaggeration or joke by other players. I beat the game a few times with different plagues, and had no real problem with them. Yet, the more I play, the more I find Greenland ending up as the last country to get infected. They're out in the middle of the ocean, so they share no borders with any other country, no planes fly to Greenland, and the only way to get to them is if an infected person in Russia or Norway travels to them by boat. If Greenland closes their seaports before they're infected, you might as well restart. The game ends up becoming a race to infect them, otherwise you'll lose because "humanity survived" despite wiping out 7,124,487,479 of 7,124,543,962 humans.It gets pretty annoying after the 4th or 5th time, but still, it's a fun game.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								Okay I might as well throw a review out there.This game is solid as a time waster, in a very satisfying and yet, incredibly challenging way. You can approach the game in a very simple mindset and have fun with it, or try to approach it tactically and find challenge in the many different ways to play each type of disease. The interface is very simplistic and some of the notifications have some witty humor to them, along side the satire news banner.Some of the best fun is naming your disease something utterly stupid, so you can laugh to yourself reading the pop-ups.The game has four difficulties, and a wide varieties of diseases each one can be developed differently for different victories. In addition to the many different countries and locations to start, each one will provide different challenges for your disease. Casual and Normal difficulty are pretty much for the average player, with normal providing some good challenge. Then the game ramps up to Brutal and the dreaded Mega Brutal in which disease seems impossible.Your goal is simply regardless of how you choose to play. Destroy humanity. Infect everyone and increase your diseases lethal level till no survivors remain. The shorter number of days it takes you to wipe out humanity, and the smaller percentage of the cure determines a scoring system.The music also sets the tone very well, and in some disease missions the music is slightly altered. The sound effects are simple but excellent for a title like this.For only $15, this game has plenty of replay value and is a ton of fun.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								Plague Inc. EVOLVED is a virus simulation where you name and create your virus, pick a host country, evolve, mutate and spread across the world until you've infected and killed every person on earth.Choose from a variety of symptoms and abilities for your virus to strategically spread and infect new countries while the remaining healthy population closes borders and works towards a cure. Unlock new abilities and infections by wiping out the human race, and add a bunch of awesome, well-made scenarios via the workshop.+ Simple interface and menus+ Comical achievements, and lots of them+ Variable gameplay speed makes for quick games+ Different strategies required for spreading your virus from game to game+ Symptom tree makes for some interesting, humorous, and sometimes dark combinations+ Impressive workshop content adds a ton to the game++ Multiplayer update for versus or co-op viral action*- Point and click point gathering system is mehFree multiplayer update and awesome workshop support make this a no-brainer*. Oh, and if a viral apocalypse ever really goes down, your best bet is to head for Greenland before they close the ports.8.5/10

								Have you ever had these queasy thoughts about humankind being terminated by the smallest of bacteriae? Have you ever wondered how a zombie-virus would go about starting the apocalypse? Have you ever wanted to kill all humans?Look no further, you've found your game! An interestingly strategic game, where you evolve your bacteria/virus/neurax worm/etc. from a harmless organism, to a massively spread and ultra deadly killer. It's especially fun on mobile devices and is also available for Android.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's a realistic and simple disease simulator with a huge amount of options while keeping it simple and player friendly.Pros You can choose one among several disease types (bacteria, virus, fungus, parasite, prion, nano-virus, bio-weapon, neurax worm, necroa virus, simian flu and more may be add in the future) You can name your plague You can choose your plague's genetic code (initial traits) You can choose on which country your plague will start from You can evolve your plague with symptoms, abilities and type of transmission The game has 4 difficulty levels being casual, normal, brutal and mega brutal they highest the difficulty the more realistic and challenging the game becomes A lot of information is displayed about world events and how the world is reacting to your plague and you can use the evolution system to evolve you plague making the best use of the events happening to help spread your pathogen Aside from the main game disease types there are official scenarios with interesting diseases to play like black beath, smallpox and much more There are also unofficial scenarios that are made by the players themselves and uploaded on steam workshop making the game have even more content The controls are simple you can basically play using mouse only or mouse plus space (pause), 1, 2 and 3 to control game speed plus q (opens abilities, symptons, transmission tabs) and e (stats tab)Cons Can't think of anyIf you like simulation games this is definitely a must buy.

number of helpful: 216 of 395 people (55%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
Early Access Review



YouTube™ Video: Plague Inc: evolved PC First Impressions 

			Views: 3,604		

			Cosmic's first impressions of Plague Inc: Evolved developed by Ndemic creations. Available now on Steam early access. Twitter - http://twitter.com/Cosmicengine99 Facebook - http://tinyurl.com/q5vpc63...		

You may be saying to yourself 'hey I've seen this game before' and you would be correct in that assumption. Plague inc was originally an iOS and android game and has now come to PC via Steam early access. Now you no doubt know what the game is all about so the purpose of this video is to inform you whether it's worth your hard earned cash.Developed by one-man developer Ndemic Creations and released originally for mobile devices in 2012 Plague inc went on to be the 15th most downloaded paid iPhone game of 2012 in the U.S. (and 18th on iPad). In March 2013, the game went on to win multiple categories of the Pocket Gamer Awards, including Overall Game of the Year. The game itself is a plague simulator, the object of the game is to infect and kill the entire world's population. Once you have selected what type of plague your going to use, be it bacteria, parasite or a myriad of other options. You then go on to select where you plague will start by selecting a country of your choice. Throughout the lifespan of your plague you can evolve it, not only increasing its infectiousness but also it's lethality. You accomplish this by purchasing various so called evolutions with DNA points. DNA points are earned naturally by the plague spreading but also by clicking the DNA and infection bubbles that pop up on the world map as the plague spreads.As your plague spreads and starts causing fatalities, authorities will start to take notice. At a certain point scientists will begin to research a cure for your plague and then the race begins to see if you can kill the populace before a cure is developed. You can hamper the cure research progress by popping the research bubbles on the main map and by also purchasing evolutions that hamper research development.I really enjoying Plague inc on my iOS device last year, I thought it was a fun little title that had some replayablity but it certainly was not a core game. So it begs the question is this title worth $15 of your hard earned cash? And before the complainers out there say, well you can't critique an early access title, I'll say this, if your asking money for a product, I'm damn well going to find out if it's worth the money for people or not.In its current state on early access, it is not worth your money especially since only the main game, which I might add is the same version as the mobile game, is available. Why spend $15 dollars on something that you can pick up for less the $3 on your mobile device. That being said there are some new features coming to the game like multiplayer, speed run mode and scenarios but even then will it be worth it?For me personally, to make the $15 really worth it, this game will have to produce a great multiplayer experience. The multiplayer needs to add what the single player experience lacks, re-playability. While the cooperative and competitive multiplayer modes do sound like fun, I do doubt it will hold people for long. I think the single player could have done will some rework too, if it was me, I would have added some micro gameplay elements in there to add to the experience. Everything in the game is on the macro level, I would have added in some new levels. For example like in spore where you start of as a cell and as you grow the level gets bigger, what you could have done here is start of in a town of a country, the aim would be first to spread your plague across the country, then the game would go onto the world level.I really feel that small changes like the addition of levels would have really added to the game and make spending $15 for what is essentially a mobile game, a more justifiable purchase. I'm not saying that Plague inc is a bad game, on the contrary its a very fun, if not superficial simulator. I simply feel that in its current state it is not worth $15 of your money, once the additional features are added especially the multiplayer, it may be worth another look. But for the time being, I'd wait either until full release or if your just interested in the single player, pick it up on your mobile device.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								Score: 7.5/10Total playtime: 31 hoursPrice: $10 or lessPlague Inc. A game of creating and evolving various types of illness to wipeout mankind. Be it bacteria, virus, parasite, zombies, simian ape flu (Planet of the Apes), nanomachine or a man made biological death virus you are tasked with infecting and ultimately wiping out humanity. Transmission, Symptom and Ability are the three areas you will dabble in making your virus hardier in different climates and against man made medicine and air / water filters. Symptoms tend to come in three areas as well. Infectivity, severity and lethality. The trick is to keep infectivity high while keeping severity and lethality low initally. Should the latter two get too high countries will begin researching a cure for your illness.While essentially the exact same game as the mobile app, the real fun comes from the Steam Workshop. Everything from demonic possession, the four horsemen of the apocalypse, Terminator-like machine uprisings, AI self awareness (I Have No Mouth and Must Scream), spider-based armaggedon, the 1982 'The Thing' and many more. Be it the coming of dragons, vampires, werewolves or transforming into a propane loving Hank Hill this game provides amusement with slight resource management and is well worth picking up on sale as a time killer.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Had my eye on this game for a while and was tempted when it recently went on sale. At the same time, I also happened to be dealing with my 3rd week of mono symptoms. In a weird sort of way, looking up information about the virus actually inspired me to finally pick this up.And I'm glad I did!To summarize, this game is basically a simulation of the transmission and evolution of a disease. You control transmission methods, symptoms, and abilities with the object being killing everyone before a cure can be created. Thinking about your decisions is crucial. Can't just kill off everyone immediately because it cannot spread. Cannot make it too passive because the cure will catch up to you. So, you have to find a balance.While it may be a dark premise, which might put some off, the game is pretty solid. Hoping multiplayer is on its way soon.Added bonus: You give your disease a name. So, have a giggle killing off the planet's inhabitants with "Kindness", "Puppies", "Mad", and "Your♥♥♥♥♥quot;.

Early Access Review
								Infecting the World and evolving a virus is fun and the game does a good work as a simulation game. However this game is not for everybody, because there is no fancy graphics or story or gameplay, so if you are not into this genre, look for something else. On the other hand, if you do like these simulation type of games, you should get this one, because it is very good in its playfield and the concept is innovative and scarry at the same time considering its real life connections. The game also has a HUGE re-playability with several different plague types with different gameplay and abilities.I'm looking forward for the future updates which may legitimate the price, but at the moment I feel the current price a bit expensive. I really hope that more plague types, game modes and evolutions will come which will further enhance the fun.Overall I have enjoyed this game even in its current state and I can recommend it but only for those, who are into this genre.

number of helpful: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								Despite this game being a simulation of a disease, it's got alot more strategy than you'd initially think. Hence it being in my Strategy games library category.Basically what you've got here is an experience akin to the mobile android game Plague Inc. Only awesomely enough it's the same cost as all the DLC for that game combined.Plus looking at the prospect of Co-op and even Competitive Multiplayer, Custom Scenarios (likely implemented via the workshop) and the existence of Speed Runs, a Leaderboard, and even a virus not currently featured in Plague Inc. The Simian Virus as a reference to the Planet of The Apes series.You start with Bacteria, Then Virus, and later control Fungus, prion and even my favorite and one of THE EASIEST plague types in the game, The Neurax Worm, a plague that is essentially a brain worm (Alpha Centauri's Mind Worms, anyone? :D) tha can either kill or mind-control, allowing for a second victory alternative.Whichever plague you start with, the object of the game is to kill all of mankind, save for the Neurax Worm which can turn all of humanity into a slave race (which in my opinion is better than killing them all).There are 7 plague types, and they all play differently, although a couple feel or act similar, no single plague works the same as another, which is the important part as nobody wants to play an FPS where 60% of the guns all act the same, or an RTS where 5 units are literally the same thing with a paint job.There is easily a wealth of content as the game itself is fairly tricky with plague types like the Necroa Virus, a plague that can turn people into zombies.... or just act like a normal plague... which doesn't work as well as when a zombie, you have abilities you can use.If you oppose Evolution, or find killing humanity in a simulation wrong somehow, or you don't like Simulations or Strategy games... Then this game isn't for you.Otherwise, if you're okay about either point, or like any of them, then I highly encourage you to get a copy of this game, It's loads of fun, allowing for more than 6-24 hours worth of gameplay if ignoring the achievements.To get them, I'd imagine that number would triple easily.This game's a blast, I personally see it as a 7/10 in it's current state, it may easily rise in the future as I just cannot forget future features like Co-op, which I am absolutely ecstatic about.So yeah. 7/10, once leaving Early access, I will come back and redo this review.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												The best way to describe this game is "A HD remake of Pandemic with a sh*t ton of new features!" Simply put, if you enjoyed Pandemic, theres no reason to hate this game, it's better in everyway.The music is good, however it can get repetitive at times.The graphics (If you can call them graphics) are nice and bright, and everything stands out so you know what is what, nothing blends in.While Pandemic had 3 diseases, this game HAS A LOT more and creative ones, plus thanks to the Steam workshop, theres pretty much an unlimted amount of diseases you can play as, plus if you want to make your own, it's very easy to learn!The game while simple and repetitive, it's still a lot of fun and has a lot of Easter Eggs in game, including a Minecraft reference and more.However theres one downside for me, and that's you unlock some of the content by playing a disease in a specific difficulty, this sounds good, but most of the time from my playthroughs, some bullcrap keeps happening like the following.I never get enough DNA points to stop the cure OR get the upgrades I need.The game has an♥♥♥♥♥pull and the cure sky rockets while the upgrades don't help at all, they barely help.Some upgrades feel like they do nothing, for an example I got an upgrade to increase lethality, but people die at the same rate as before.If my disease has nearly no severity, it will get spotted no matter what... this is really unfair when I have a PIXAL amount of severity and I pretty much lose when I just started the game.When I try to play sneaky and spread then kill, I keep getting random upgrades because my disease is evolving, this can help, but most of the time ruins the game for me.I would have prefered to have all the stuff unlocked at the start and have "Beat this difficulty with X disease" just as achievements, rather then having it locked.Overall it's a fun and basic game, if you enjoy Pandemic, theres no reason to say no to this game.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												Let me preface this by saying that I am not good at this game.I mean, I get the way the game works, and I'm not hopeless, but as of this writing, I've put in nearly 100 hours and still haven't unlocked cheats.  And while that is largely due to the fact that I don't want to try Bioweapon again, it is also illustrative of why I recommend this game so highly.  You don't have to be good at Plague Inc. to play it and have fun with it.At its core, Plague Inc. is a casual game.  You pop bubbles with your finger or mouse, tap or click to choose how your disease progresses, and that's it.  However, where this game differs from most casual games is that the developers have created layers of strategy and complexity over that basic framework, layers that individual players can freely embrace or ignore as they see fit.  If you don't particularly care about factors like how many uninfected countries have dry climates as opposed to wet climates or how to best target the countries that are advancing cure research, then you can simply ignore them, play on casual, and evolve whatever you feel like.  However, if you are looking for more challenge and depth than the average casual gamer, then you can crank up the difficulty to normal. brutal, or even mega-brutal, and carefully plot out which combinations of symptoms, transmission vectors, and other abilities will lead you to victory.In short, Plague Inc. has something for everyone, from the most casual of casual players ro the hardest of hardcore gamers, and I highly recommend it.Now, if you'll excuse me, I'm going to go swear and flail uselessly at the new Shadow Plague disease type some more.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								It's easy to look at a game like this, one that you played a few times on your phone, and say "Oh boy another horrible mobile to PC port." Well I can confidently tell you that that is not the case. General Pros:~ Easibly navigable GUI and map screen~ Detailed explanations of the implications of your in-game actions~ Random events that can help or hinder your plauges growth~ Fun upgrade paths that are exciting to explore and discover~ Multiple plauge types each with their own special abilities and upgrade pathsThe real question, however, is 'why should i buy this game on my PC if i already payed 5 bucks for it on my phone'?PC Pros:~ 3 all new plauge types that are very different from the generic plauges of the phone game (A zombie plauge, A Planet of the Apes Plauge, and a Plauge that allows you to partially control the infected!)~ Better controls, A 0prettier and more easily navigated GUI, and the ability to go 3X speed (The Phone only has 2X)~ Hundreds of awesome user made scenarios that allow you to plauge the world with everything from Evil Ninjas, to Cults of Cthulu Worshipers~ EXTREMELY easy to use Modding system (included with the game) that allows you to edit virtually every aspect of the game~ An Indev (in Development) multiplayer version.The cons to this game are minimal. While the core of the game remains constant with each new disease you play as, the depth, story, and gameplay can change greatly with different scenarios, mods, and disease types. If you can try to pick this game up on sale, after having spent $5 on the game for my phone i didnt really want to pay full price again, but on the same token i would snatch this game up while its still in the early access stage, because for the content it has and will have i would definitly want to get it before the price goes up.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2016
 Can you infect the world? Plague Inc is a unique sandbox/strategy/simulation game in which you'll be able to play up to 8 different types of deadly diseases with one main goal: To infect and kill every single person in the world. Sounds morbid? Well, it surely is!Upon launching a match you'll first get to choose the disease you want to play - you'll also get to choose one of four difficulty levels - the least one being really though - even for long term players. After this you'll skip to a map of the earth and here you'll get to choose a starting country and from there on you gotta use the skill system (3 skill trees which differ - depending on your disease - all of them using DNA which you'll gather during the match) to overcome the obstacles which the game will throw at you. You'll develop more efficient transmission/resistance abilities to spread further and infect more people - as well as symptoms to spread and later to kill. The setup is very realistic, with a ton of countries, climate zones and random events to make every match you play unique. Note that every match is 45 minutes to 2h long - depending on how you're playing. You're able to save and revisit your match at any given point.At first you'll only able to play as bacteria but upon winning a match you'll unlock the next disease-type. You'll also unlock genes to modify your diseases to make them more resistant to their environment and to generally strengthen them (this enables possibilities to differ in strategies and  YES, there IS a zombie disease ). I should mention that there aren't any graphics aside of the skilltrees and the map on which planes and ships are moving around and infection bubbles popping up - but those are enough to make it an entangling and fun game. The soundtrack is very good - and there are sometimes slight noises like coughing or children playing depending on how far your disease has spread. In the end everything is silent - a pretty sinister and strong impression if you'd ask me!I should also mention that there is a enjoyable multiplayer with PvP and  Co-op and a scenario creator as well as tons of archievements and scenarios - most of them for more experienced players!This game is extremely fun despite having such a scary background and I really recommend it to you if you're interested in diseases and tactical simulations with much freedom and many ways to approach your goal!

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
Early Access Review
Very enjoyable game!Similar to the Flash game Pandemic (or Pandemic 2), if you have not played one of those and are interested in this game, I really do suggest to try them out first to get a feel for the type of gameplay.Plague Inc is essentially a more refined version of Pandemic, with more features, more gameplay elements, more intersting evolutions, more more more!Your task is simple; develop a pathogen to infect and kill the entire humankind. :)There are many different ways to achieve this goal and each time you manage to complete it you unlock a new type of pathogen and a new gene which can be used the next time you play.There are currently (24th June 2014) 9 different pathogens, for which you can select 5 gene slots, each slot has 5 different genes to choose from.Genes are a way to get different starting stats on your pathogen, for example "Darwinist" increases the chance of your plague mutating, "Aerocyte" increases chance of plague spreading by air. Your choice of pathogen and genes will affect your gameplay.The challenge of the game is to try and beat the game with all kinds of pathogens, they have different types of mutations that you can research with some unique attributes and abilities.The game is a tablet/mobile port, which is noticeable by some of the UI but in this type of game it isn't really an issue.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								I can highly recommend this game. For those who are already familiar with the mobile version:All additional content is or will be included but has to be unlocked during play. The visual presentation was adjusted for the PC and looks way better. The world map looks beautiful, and the country pages now include a textual description and camera surveillance. You get much more stats about how your plague is performing, and as a bonus, you can save and load your game at any time. Other gaming modes like speed run and campaigns will be added, but those seem to be added to the mobile version as well.For those new to the game:You get a quick to play, casual strategy game with an interesting theme and excellent visual presentation. On first glance, it may seem repetitive to just having to add perks until all humanity is wiped out. But the different plague types and random events require different strategies. It's quite rewarding when you succeed with your plague on the harder difficulty levels. As an additional challenge you can try to get the over 50 achievements, some of those are very interesting and require additional thought.Pricing and Early Access:I won't discuss the price as it is a personal choice of how much one wants to pay for a game. But compared to many other mobile ports, this one stands out because it was adjusted to PC standards and not just copied over. Also, for an early access game, it is quite stable and the basic gameplay is already there. I did not encounter any bugs, there are of course some very minor issues.Summary:If you are on the edge, and the price is ok, then buy it without any doubt. If it seems too expensive, then at least get and try the mobile version. There will be a steam sale eventually ;-)

content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a very good game... almost my top 5 favorites actually.Won't lie, I got this for my best friend in real life. Didn't even have any interest for it at the time... however, due to the game's popularity and increased number of positive reviews, I purchased it for myself. Did not regret it in the slightest.Unlike most strategy games, you REALLY have to consider how to indirectly make your virus (or disease) wipe out humanity. Every little choice matters, and can affect you in the long run. What I love about this game, is that humanity doesn't die easily even on, well, easy mode! They'll fight it till the end, and it's fun seeing who'll win. You or the world.Every feature is unique, and I haven't seen a game like this in a long while. Everything that happens is recorded, you will get News of the latest events until your virus becomes deadly (or known) enough to make countries start worrying. It's realistic too since countries will start coming up with ways (news wise, or strategy wise) to stop your virus from killing everyone. It doesn't even stop there-The more you unlock, the crazier (or creative) it becomes in you wiping out humanity. Extremely fun, plus the game is nice enough to let you speed things up since it can take awhile for the infection to spread country to country. Best way in taking any mode on is to make your virus spread quickly without hurting people (even a cough will make doctors eventually look into curing it.) Luckily you can devolve your virus's symptoms so that it doesn't end up drawing attention. Not to mention you can name your virus anything, and a LOT of events can occur in which your last run didn't activate. I somehow caused Japan to have a nuclear plant explode ... and that's just 1 out of the 103 events lol.I give it a solid 9.5/10 and it's just in Alpha. I cannot wait till it's fully done. I also wonder how multiplayer will work?

content:
Posted: October 16, 2016
Plague Inc. Evolved begins with you selecting a country to begin your disease. There can be a lot of strategy involved even at this stage as you’ll gain resistances to certain effects, but at the same time you may have trouble infecting other countries. There are numerous factors to take into account such as airports and harbours, the climate of the country, if the country is rich or poor – poorer countries will be less capable of dealing with disease – and if the country is an island.You gain DNA points periodically over the course of the game and you’ll gain more by infecting new countries, popping DNA bubbles on the map and generally just spreading your disease. Devolving certain symptoms also yields a refund of DNA points if you need them. Symptoms, transmissions and abilities (such as resistances to drugs and certain weather) all cost DNA points.Each pathogen is distinctly different and each one require different strategies. Bacteria is the most basic pathogen which is easy to master, viruses can mutate very quickly and can quickly get out of control and funguses are hard to spread. Some pathogens also have unique gameplay modifiers to them such as the neurax worm – which can manipulate minds. The neurax worm is able to develop a trait that allows you to fly infected planes to uninfected countries. The necroa virus allows you to control zombie hordes and send them into other countries.Plague Inc. Evolved can also be played on 4 difficulty levels – casual, normal, brutal and mega brutal. Normal mode is the most realistic interpretation of how a disease might spread as the game treats 67% of the world’s population as regularly washing their hands and doctors only work a standard amount of days per week. Sick people will also be ignored.Higher difficulties have 100% of people washing their hands, doctors working non-stop and sick people will be locked up in prison. Plague Inc. Evolved is a mobile/PC port of a game to PC that is done right. Really a great game for the money.THE GOOD- Insane number of factors being simulated- Great customization options- Easy to pick up and play- Humorous scenarios- 10 Different Disease Types- 20 Unique ScenariosTHE BAD- Co-Op matchmaking is defect- Low replay value for campaign missionsDISASTER | BAD | MEDIOCRE | OKAY | GOOD | GREAT | AMAZING | MASTERPIECE

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
Early Access Review
Full disclosure: I'm a strategy game junkie, and am therefore more likely to view them favorably.Plague Inc is a "God Game" map game where the goal is to transmit pathogens to all the zones on the map. The player selects a type of pathogen and a starting location, and then manages the development of the pathogen by evolving attributes like abilities, infection vectors, and symptoms, typically to spread the furthest possible before anyone notices, and then bringing on the symptoms like a sledgehammer to become as virulent and dangerous as possible to thwart research efforts.The Good Highly innovative adaptation of the traditional Risk-style "map game" Solid gameplay, good controls, decent pacing Strangely satisfying to see a country hit that threshhold where your virus gets runaway growth and red floods the region Also strangely satisfying to thwart human efforts at a cure. Seeing the research bar making negative progress, or even better: when you go virulent so quickly that the UN plane never appears, or where the world is dead but some ports never got closed... very satisfying indeed! Fun to try out different sets of genes and symptoms and watch the results Developers continue to stay engaged, despite the fact that the game really is DONE. New scenarios get dropped from time to time to keep the game fresh and new. The Nureaux Worm spreading Christmas Cheer was especially cute and fun. Nureaux Worm in general is just amazingly fun Nice quick game. Game time is about as long as it should be for a game of this complexity. It never gets to the point of "Are we there yet?" Planet of the Apes tie-in is brilliant Cool musicThe Bad The single biggest "bad" IMHO is the number of things that players have to unlock. I wanted to play as a Prion right away, but you have to GRIND through several previous stages to get there. It really feels a bit like jumping through hoops. Strategies don't change much. For the most part, you want to (1) infect everyplace before anybody has discovered you, (2) get as deadly and dangerous as possible once its likely you will infect everybody. The only real exceptions to this are the Nano Virus, where you start out discovered, and the Zombie Virus, where zombies can continue to spread the plague. Even the symptom selection is pretty straightforward, but I won't get into that because discussing those strategies would constitute spoilers. Some game modes are extremely hard without unlocking genetic starting abilites. For example, the zombie virus you really need to play as Creationist or there's little chance of getting the whole world. Yet I got the Zombie virus long before I got the creationist gene, and wasted a lot of time on an (arguably) unwinnable scenario. Humans develop cures unrealistically fast, even on easy mode. I suspect that developers decided the speed of research by choosing what was challenging for the player, not for any type of realistic scenario. I mean... how long have we been trying to find a cure for AIDS? While it makes for a better game, it weakens Plague Inc as a simulation. Bubble Popping mini-game is silly and should just be eliminated. You "pop bubbles" all over the map for 3 different scenarios: to collect a bit of evolution (orange), the patient zero in any new country (red), or to squash ongoing research (blue). These reflex mini games really have no purpose in a strategy or simulation game. I suspect this was added because this was released for tablet too, and they needed to give players stuff to reflex-poke to make them feel engaged. (PC Gaming Master Race has a longer attention span, and doesn't need trivial casual mini-games to stay engaged) Random Events can really determine victory or defeat, especially on really close games. If you've read my reviews before, I'm sure you're well-aware that I consider dicerolls in strategy games non-strategic, and a no-no. Plague Inc really relies heavily on dicerolls, whether for random events, mutations, "drops", or deciding whether or not an infection spreads onto a transmission vector (plane, boat (etc)). There are no dice rolls in chess. Strategy games should be about strategy alone, not luck. Name never made sense to me. Plague Inc? Where's the Inc? You play as a virus, not a company.ConclusionGreat game, despite some minor blunders to cater it towards mobile audiences (bubble popping and unlockables). Otherwise its an awesome concept well-executed. Its a smallish game with short "levels", so if you're looking for deep rich gameplay or a story, this one might not be for you. It really is more of a simulation, despite the gamified elements. But I enjoyed it thoroughly. And now I know that Greenland is probably the best place to be, if there's ever a plague.Thanks for reading!

Early Access Review
								I was a little reluctant to buy this as I can play Pandemic 2 for free as an online Flash game, but I'm glad I DID buy it!  Although it's Early Access, the main single-player campaign is fully playable and I've encountered no serious bugs at all (multiplayer and new single-player missions are now being worked on for later addition).  The game has taken care of all the irritations of the online Pandemic (where Madagascar would slam shut its borders as soon as anyone merely stubbed their toe, meaning game over), diseases can cross borders via birds and insects even when border controls are closed and there are more factors to meddle with in the hope of being evil and spreading your new disease before anyone has chance to notice and work on a cure.  Additionally, successful completions of the game unlock new bonus traits you can collect and use to develop your own mutations and improve your chances of winning.The developers have made an excellent job of the game and I'm glad they brought it from app to PC.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Definitely worth the $15. If you've played this game on iOS or Android, skip this paragraph. Plague Inc is a world-ending virus simulator. It started out on iPhone a few years ago and was a huge success. It consistently topped app charts, had a number of really cool free updates, and it just gives you so much to do. The CDC even liked it enough to meet with the app creator and discuss how to make it more realistic! In this game, you control a plague (bacteria, virus, fungus, man-made plague, brain worm, and more...there's a lot to choose from). You choose where the virus begins, and you watch as it spreads across the world. You control what vectors the virus uses, how the virus defends itself against temperature and medicine, and what symptoms the virus produces (oh, and I'm just going to use "virus" as shorthand for "plague" just because I'm more used to typing "virus"). There's a lot of strategy involved, whether you try to create a nearly invisible virus that, when detected, it will be too late or if you try to create a virus that becomes scarier and scarier as it spreads and just overwhelms cure efforts. The game has been balanced to really support both options. As you infect people, new countries, and kill people, you gain DNA points that you use to alter your virus. The scarier that your virus is, the more you're rewarded with points, but the more that every scientist in the world focuses on curing you. Don't worry, however - the game does a great job of explaining everything to you. Whereas a game like Pandemic can be really intimidating with all of these different medical terms (even one for runny nose - are you kidding me?), Plague Inc prefers to use the common words for symptoms. You're not overloaded with choices (but there are enough for you) and the impact each DNA change has is clearly shown (such as infectivity, lethality, and how scary it appears to the world).For those who have played it on mobile, not much has really changed. Each plague is unlocked after beating the previous one, there's the world map, unlockable gene bonuses, etc. However, it doesn't really look too polished as of yet. The UI feels outdated and inexplicably cheap. I almost feel like I'm playing a flash game in my browser. The UI is mostly functional, but has a lot of empty space. It also has some elements that are just for show rather than solving a purpose. For example, a bar graph to the right of the country status indicator (the main bar on the UI) has different colored bars that don't represent anything and don't move. I don't know why they're there. It's still early access, so that may change. Also, every country has a picture of it (mostly just showing people and buildings, maybe a landmark). The pictures look like cheap CGI (god knows why - there's no shortage of real pictures of locations), but there are maybe 10 - or less - pictures used for every country in the world. I don't mean that, say, Sudan cycles through 10 pictures. I mean that Sudan, and "West Africa," "East Africa," and "South Africa" (along with most of the rest of the continent) all have the same picture. Cheap CGI with nothing moving. At first I thought it was a neat touch, but that kind of shallowness stands in contrast to how fleshed out the rest of the game is.On the upside, each plague type has its own 3D image that reacts as you upgrade it. It doesn't change as dramatically as the neurax worm on mobile, but it will stretch out and rebound a bit when you upgrade it and wince when you devolve a feature. I think that's pretty neat, and it doesn't feel as cheap. The DNA upgrade menu is definitely an improvement. Also, the world status menu has been solidified and now has all of the important info on one screen. That's a huge improvement.Also, this game has Steam workshop integration, meaning that people are submitting their own plague types. I saw one for a Hank Hill virus earlier today. It looks like people are going to have a lot of fun creating and customizing their own plagues, and I think that's great!In summation, it's the same as the mobile game, but with a new UI (with its ups and downs) and steam workshop support.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												This game is great. I've been playing on mobile for more than two years, and I must say that this version is more challenging. Since everyone has reviewed the single player, I am going to review the competitive side!In vs mode, you are pitted against another (human!) player. You start out with un-modified bacteria, and you participate in games to unlock more stuff. One thing to remember is that tactics that worked on single-player may totally shaft you! For instance, all genes now have postives and negatives, and you may only use three at once! For plague types, there are currently three- your starter Bacteria, which has losts its ability; and two others unlocked at five victories: Virus and Bioweapon. The gameplay itself is fairly simple- upon starting, everyone is given a short amount of time to find a country to settle down in. You may NOT both start in the same country! The starter phase is hide and seek. Depending on what country you started in, you start with different amounts of DNA. You also continue to get DNA bubbles... until you starting location has been found out. The other team then gets a boost in DNA. Note: Being a high-profile disease tends to work poorly in concealing your starting point. It is hard to see the other disease's locations at first.For abilities and perks, they switched it around A LOT. Your stardard Air and Water traveling transmisisons are now teamed up with Dust (Arid) and Sweat (Humid). For symptoms, the previous symptoms are joined by 2 orange ones. These will unlock a tree that will either make the enemy plague's carriers easier to infect, or protect your own. Both are useful. Abilities has a serious overhaul. There is an ability that lets you fly planes to uninfected countries (like Trojan planes!), an ability that focuses cure research on your opponent in that area, and a buff that increases lethality and infectivity for BOTH diseases. All in all, I would give the multiplayer an 8/10. It's not perfect, but it is extremely promising! I will look forward to Co-Op mode in the future!

number of helpful: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								Note: It's Early Access for now, but I'm pretty sure the basics of the game aren't going to change dramatically between now and release.Remember a flash game by the name of Pandemic 2? (Some of you will probably recall cursing Madagascar for ruining your runs on it. Yeah. That one.) PIE is similar (in fact, I suspect its "casual" difficulty setting is based on that game), but a more well-researched and broad title. You start with nothing but bacteria as your plague of choice, but victories will unlock gene modifiers (for starting boosts) and new types of medium. That last chunk is where the craziness comes in: sure, viruses basically play like a more mutatable bacteria, but then you begin unlocking the real weird ones, like a fungus (such a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥♥to spread...), or mind-altering worms (suddenly, the goal can go from "kill the world" to "enslave every living thing"), or nanobots trying to thwart their kill-switch... the list goes on, more are still being added, and each plays distinct from the others while keeping the basics of the game, so what you learn with one can carry over to the others.If you worry it's just going to be a pushover, play with the varying difficulty settings or some of the mutator genes you get for victories. Figure out what types of symptoms combine to make you more effective, or take on the double-edged sword of being incredibly mutation-happy. All of a sudden, your disease isn't communicable ENOUGH, and your hosts are dying before infecting others...I really dig this, but you've gotta keep in mind, this is a dark game. It's a frighteningly-realistic simulator of ending the friggin world with disease (or worse). Victory is literally a mass extinction in most scenarios. I would absolutely NOT recommend this for everyone just based on that.

content:
Posted: April 16
												My personal study of Plague Inc: Evolved, a game in which you can destroy or conquer the world, as you like, with the deadliest (and funniest) diseases and pathogens you can think of !Pros:- Game developers keep adding official diseases, including the Simian Flu from the "Planet of the Apes" movie, Vampire and Zombie plagues, as well as more basic pathogens.- With the amazing Scenario Creator tool, you will never lack for new game experiences, and you can make up your own ! The Plague Inc. Workshop is filled with amazing addons.- The game design is incredibly realistic and well-made. Game graphisms have simply beautiful.- You can watch your disease reach every corner of the world, and even zoom on what its precise effects are on the infected victims ! You also have access to statistics showing you all there is to know about your plague and how humanity reacts, on a worldwide or a country's scale.- Since Multiplayer was added (thank you so much...), you can team up with or fight another player's plague to eradicate humanity.And so much more to say...Cons: I played so much my diseases infected me... Hope I haven't caught Ebola *cough cough*In short, a simply awesome game ! Even the CDC was impressed :)My counsel: buy it, infect, evolve... and as the developers say with each update, stay healthy ! (pretty hard to do once you start playing *cough cough*)

content:
Posted: January 30
												The first time I played PI was as a free mobile game, with pay2win content. I hated it for that. When they decided to go for full-on paid game, I was sceptical. In hindsight, it was the best decision they could have made.They used the added income to polish the game. Add more types of diseases, more scenarios, multiplayer, etc. They've made a short-lived mobile-game into a multiplatform game that you can play over and over again. The various scenarios play differently. Different approaches are required for different missions. Imho, they should have gone with the full-on-game approach from the start, but at least they managed to fix initial mistakes and make it a game worth paying for.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16
												This game is unlike any other I've played. I recommend it if you like strategy games and want to challenge yourself. It's brutal-especially on the difficulties of the same name haha. This game is about creating and mutating various plagues to wipe out mankind. You might not think it, but this is actually a great game to play with a group of friends. It's perversely satisfying when you and a group of friends get together and simulate various ways to wipe out humanity-whether it be with an ancient brain controlling worm, a prion, a mechanical bioweapon, a simple virus or bacteria. They even added more plagues than that which is a large part of why I love this game so much. It would have been great as it was, but they weren't satisfied and added a vampiric plague that allows you to create vampires and enslave humanity, or you could wipe out the world with a zombie apocalypse, and they added a Planet of the Apes type plague that allowed you to mess around with the idea of using sentient apes to destroy humanity. The amount of thought and depth they put into each of those three new plagues impresses me and is the main reason I will always come back to play this. It's a great game whether you're looking to just kill a couple hours, or trying to game all week. There are a bunch of scenarios that let you play out various situations either made up or from history to keep you interested if you get bored of the main game. Scenarios like the black plague, or an infectious happiness disease. This game even has multiplayer so you can play online with your friends or other people. I haven't tried it out yet, but I know it has both co-op and competitive modes for whether you want to work with or crush others online. I also like that it rewards you for completing games by unlocking additional genes to implant in your plagues to help give them a boost (help them spread faster) in certain environments or help them remain unseen for longer. These are essential if you're going to try and beat any of the plagues on their highest difficulties. Seriously-this game is beautifully difficult. The genes aren't necessary for normal gameplay, but they do make it easier and more fun to try to more manually direct how your plague spreads at first. For example: I like starting out in Saudi Arabia or India. They're both arid, hot climates and I often give my plague a gene boost in arid climates and a boost to spreading by land because they are both connected to a ton of landmass and arid climates. However, I could also have chosen genes that gave my plague a boost in cold and/or humid climates to help my plague spread once it leaves it's starting environment. Since all your plagues get a slight bonus to the environment type they start in (makes sense, right?) it might be more beneficial to me to plan ahead and help my plague out in climates that it normally would be fairly ineffective in.All in all, if you like a good strategy game and the idea of wiping out humanity in any way appeals to you-I recommend trying this game out. It's worth your time and money whether it's on sale or full price.

								Plague Inc: Evolved is a game about a topic very near and dear to my heart: Big Pharma.In Plagues Incorporated: Evolutions, you play an intrepid reporter looking to expose the lies of Big Pharma; you slowly uncover things like AIDS being created by the CIA and the flu vaccine actually causing autism. Both vs of 2 diseases fighting to infect everyone and co-op 2 diseases trying to kil humanity together. This used to be a fun multiplayer. Used to be. Now? Its a frustrating chore for Multiplayer. Everyone looks at the guide and does the exact same stuff, upp symptoms, use airplane special abb to move your disease to china, india, south Africa and Brazil to infect most people. College Humour did a comic animated short of 7 deadly sins of gaming. And guess which one this game is currently taking up? No go on watch the 7 deadly sins and get back to me.If you want a fun experience going againt the computer player on sing player go for it very fun, interesting scenarios it shoves in there. Stay away from multiplayer. Its like playing C&C where everyone builds super weapons and spams away. This game everyone gets airplane special and spams away. Frustrating chore.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Once, an app that started out on the IPhone, and went onto Android. I browsed on the Steam Store one day and found out that Plague Inc. moved onto PC.The PC version is far different than the smart phone Appilication version. This version looks a lot better (since computers can handle MUCH more than just a smart phone) and feels more smooth. The concepts are about the same.The PC version is a vast improvement since it's appilication version. Graphics have obviously improved. Some little things they've added onto the game really make a difference in setting this version from the app.It's a lot easier to (if you're not good at geography) locate where countries are in the world menu. I'm very good at geography, so that was never a problem for me in the first place, but its a very nice addon. The diseases themselves have animations, and the water in the world menu has animations aswell, thus making the game look prettier. This game, like the app version, is very addicting.Overall, this game deserves best, and even though it's currently in early access alpha, I still rate it a:10/10.

Great game - play it for the fun and frightening realism.

content:

Early Access Review
								I bought this game a while back, and since then many new features have come out. Many of you will probably be thinking, 'Oh, this game costs £11 but on the phone is only costs £2!' The price point of this game is a bit steep, so buy it on sale, it regualy goes down to £8. I myself have the phone version, but the interface and the mass of scenarios makes it worth the money. Also, theres no ads! Yes this game is still in very early access, as many of the features like multiplayer are unavailable. However, the different plague types and the scenarios will keep you going for a while, and even if you complete them you can create your own plague of download one off the community workshop. Overall, I would give this game a 9/10, and this game should be amazing when fully complete.

content:

Early Access Review
								I've always enjoyed booting up Pandemic II from time to time, and I'm really happy with how much Plague Inc improved on the experience! The upgrades you choose for your disease have intuitive effects and matter a lot with how well (and where) the disease survives and spreads. You can't help but develop an evil grin when you see [insert funny disease name] finally start to balloon across nations.It's a great game for killing time now and then, multitasking with your other activites, and slightly freaking people out when they ask you what you're doing.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22
												Plague Inc. is a game where you control a plague & your goal is to eliminate all life on Earth. This is accomplished by upgrading your disease, whether it be bacteria, a virus, or something else, to increase it's infectivity, severity, and lethality so you can infect & kill more and more people.Anyway, overall I like this game. There's  a lot of different things in the game that you can do to have a unique and fun experience like different forms of a disease you can choose from (bacteria, virus, etc.), different difficulties (casual, brutal, etc.) and other ways of creating a unique experience. You can even take over the world with apes! The game is strategic and can be very challenging. However, that's the fun of it, especially when you can name your disease a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ meme & have the end message of "xd has eradicated all life on Earth" or something like that.But anyway, definetly reccomend trying out this game for anyone considering to do so. Challenging, fun, and rewarding. Great game if your into strategy games & destroying the world.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								I usually dispise early access games, after purchasing a few dozen of them, I know failures when I see them. Plague is a very simple type of game wth very complex mechanics, Easy to learn, yet challenging. I'll start with the pro's then move to the cons.-PRO'S-Variety of pathogens to choose from-Each pathogen has its on quirks and methods of killing-Each pathogen requires you to take a different approach to transmition-The BGM tends to draw out your inner bio terrorist and really allows you to immerse yourself into the game-The many adaptations and genes to each pathogen add more replayability to the game.-As far as I can tell, There are no bugs (Atleast for me)-the game can be either fast pace or slow depending on your playstyle.-Devs so far seem to be activeCONS- there is a part where you will need to grind early on pathogens to achieve genes to assist you with some of the pathogens that cannot be transmitted as fast on a large scale. (This is very minor)-Games like this struggle with replayability, though this game trys its best to conquer that, after 12 hours of playing it can be a little repetitive. While every scenario and every game prevents different challenges, you find yourself trying to conquer the same feats (Transmitting your virus to the same island countries...Damn you greenland)SUMMERY-While Plague is still early access, the content is def there, the game is very enjoyable and coming from a major in patho and microbiology the simulation is very accurate to what you could expect in real life scenarios. $15 is a well worth it. My hats off to the devs, I apologize for my grammer, punctuation, run ons, spelling and blah blah blah.. its 6am and I have been spreading aids for the last 12 hours. and on that note... I have had more enjoyment playing plague then I have any other early access game. I def reccommend this game to everyone. I hope to see you spreading aids soon XD

content:

Early Access Review
								If you like strategy games and destroying the world then this game is for you. It also updates frequently which is pretty cool. I would give this game a 7/10 and I think that is a fair score. All of the viruses and other microbs are unique. Some are hard while others are easy. They also have unique scenarios that you can play which are difficult. The downside to this game is that it gets repetetive. If you do not have the willpower to keep trying again after failing 4 times then this game is not for you. You can cheat and look up guides to kill the world. Also this game is time consuming and if you don't pay attention you can miss valuable resources.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game reminds me a great deal of Pandemic on Kongregate (and other sites, I suspect) - in many ways, it plays almost identically. But it's a far, far more polished version. It feels like the Blizzard take on Pandemic - polished up to an addictive shine. There's a lot more items to 'research' with your DNA points, more countries to infect, and a variety of different kinds of diseases to choose from. And then it adds additional features that make it far more interesting - combos of different symptoms with special effects, the ability to choose your starting country, cross-country animal-based infection, random events that can help or hinder your progress... The game's not done yet (this review written during Early Access) and it's already completely and totally supplanted Pandemic in my mind.And this time, you have options in case someone sneezes in New York and Madagascar CLOSES EVERYTHING. :D
