								Not bad for alpha stage. Feels good to be able to destroy humanity :P The start menu seems promising; there are official scenarios, custom scenarios and even multiplayer. Sometimes there are random mutations which might get annoying because you want a sneaky pathogen but the random mutation makes it deadly.I like the difficulty levels. There are 4. 'Casual, Normal, Brutal, Mega Brutal'. Casual is fairly easy no one washes their hands there are no researches to destroy your pathogen. Normal, some people wash their hands some doctors work so they might discover the sickness. Brutal, THEY LOCK SICK PEOPLE IN PRISON :D Mega brutal, is even worse :D I'm currently playing on brutal and stuck on 3rd pathogen because before i spread it to everyone some countries already restrict access :(I recommend it but feel like price is a bit high

content:
Posted: May 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								Virus strategy games are making leaps and bounds. I was really looking forward to such games to come to the Steam Market.For years now I've been playing a little flash game called "Pandemic", of which this is like the parent of. This game is absolutely great. It's difficult to beat, really makes you think and it does hold your hand a little, but scoots you on your merry way.Pandemic was a simple interface. You clicked maybe three or four buttons. Start in random counties. Told you when all borders were closed or all flights are gone. Check boxes for symptoms and infectivity. Still let me enjoy killing time.Pandemic 2 was more difficult. You had to watch a video tutorial to understand more about this game. For a flash game, bringing in a more RTS feel to it was alright. At the time it puzzled me and made me turn my nose, heading back for the first game.However, this is about Plague Inc.Only a few hours in and the fun and frustration is flooding back to me. You can say a hearty "F*&# you, Madagascar, I'm going to infect you, first!" But when you're initially going to infect them, you notice little icons above their information. The fact that they've incoorperated statuses like Wealth, Humidity, Hot or Cold gives a major challange. Finding places that are less rural and more densely populated is great for growing viruses. You have to take more into account when you're trying to spread your nasty plague upon the world.My advice? Do buy this game. Help the developers become a pandemic (Hehe) upon this market.It is definitely worth the $15.00 and the tasty demo on Android really got me into this.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								Some games you play to build empires. Others you play to shoot things in the head. This one... you play to exterminate humanity. Fun!Plague Inc: Evolved is a game where you make horrible diseases, spread em around the world, and try to kill everyone before those pesky humans make a cure for your plague. There is strategy involved, but there is some luck too which can be rather frustrating (F***ing Greenland). The game is fun, but also relatively easy to master. Once you figure out how things work, the challenge is mostly gone. Good thing this game has plenty of opportunities for messing around.The variety comes in the form of each different type of plague having different strengths or weaknesses, like viruses mutating alot which can lead to your disease being detected earlier than you would like. Most of the plagues are real, but the imaginary ones allow for some comic situations to arise. The Neurax Worm allows you to mind control people, leading humans to either kill themselves or worship the worm as a god. And, of course, the Necroa Virus, which allows you to unleash the zombie apocalypse rather than fighting it. The game can get a bit repetitive in time, but there is alot of crazy fun to be found as well. So, if you want to play a game where murdering everyone is the objective, then this is one that can possibly satisfy. :)

content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								Plague Inc: Evolved has evolved beyond its roots as a mobile game, and its inspiration, Pandemic 2. Even at $15, it's worth it.For those who have only played Pandemic 2 and are wondering if this is better or merely an inferior ripoff, it's definitely a more comprehensive, fleshed-out, less frustrating, more entertaining game, even if the premise is very similar. All the skills (from avian transmission to projectile vomiting) are useful, and while some strategies are more prevalent than others, there's no be-all-end-all way to win the game like there is in Pandemic 2. I'm ten hours in and I'm still finding new ways to win against the odds.The visuals are vastly improved over the mobile iteration, with red transmission dots forming across the world map as countries fall victim to your plague, 3D renders of your plague hovering in the menus, and image feeds of the cities popping up as they descend from normalcy into chaos. The devs will be adding online multiplayer, Steam Workshop support, and tutorials (amongst other features) in the upcoming weeks/months, but it's more than playable now and I definitely recommend it if you loved Pandemic and want a superior version of it.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2016
												Ninety percent of the games play the same- you infect the world and the plague slowly spreads.  You do not add any symptoms as they cause the plague to be discovered (and quickly cured).  This renders most of the symptoms pointless- as you don't dare use them.  Once everyone in the world is infected (which normally means waiting for greenland which is very cold, and very isolated) you quickly turn the disease lethal - from totally asymptomatic to a heart stopping, system killing death machine.  You then buy the abilities that stop or slow research and watch the world die.The main wrinkle is mutation which will randomly generate symptoms for your disease- there are basically two types of diseases, ones which allow you to cancel those and get resources back, the other that costs resources to cancel.  First type is very easy, second type can randomly screw your run by mutating before its fully spread and starting the cure clock.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								Greetings fellow gamers! This is Gamer Guy (In a Suit) from the Echo Army YouTube channel! Today I am bringing you a review of an intriguing little Simulator-type game called Plague, Inc. Plague, Inc has been around on mobile devices for a while, and on Steam since February 20, 2014. It is still in Early Access, but Publisher/Developer Ndemic Creations is VERY active, having just recently added the highly anticipated Competitive Multiplayer mode.(NOTE: This was a review from a game in my own Steam library, it was NOT provided by the Developer and/or Publisher)Video Review:


YouTube™ Video: Plague Inc Evolved Review - Steam 

			Views: 332		

			Join the Echo Army ► http://bit.ly/1KD1iv3 Twitter ► http://bit.ly/1LiIQ59 Facebook ► http://on.fb.me/1M0Comd Buy Plague Inc Evolved on Steam: http://store.steampowered.com/app/246620/...		

The "Too Long, Didn't Watch" Review:Great game, good casual way to pass time OR you can ramp up the difficulty and give yourself fits. Highly replayable. Active Devs. Another 4/5 on an incomplete game? Yup. Worth $15 easily.The "Meat & Potatoes" Review:I picked this game up a long time ago on my iPhone and loved it, so when it came to Steam I picked it up about a year ago around Xmas. I stashed it away, awaiting it's release from Early Access. Well, I couldn't wait and the newly updated Multiplayer mode gave me an excuse to review it anyways! Now, I didn't review the MP mode simply because I wanted gamers to get a feel for the actual game itself first. This game is a simulation game where you are trying to spread a disease and essentially wipe out mankind. You get points to evolve your disease in different categories (Transmission, Symptoms, Abilities) to try and help it spread and eradicate humanity. Meanwhile, the world works against you by crafting a cure, shutting down airports/harbors, etc. Pesky humans, you'll find, are quite resiliant. As you play and get better at the game you unlick different types of diseases and starting genomes for your disease. There is a lot here and this is all fun on it's own, but then you incorporate things like Steam Workshop, User Made Scenarios, Multiplayer and the like, and the replayability shoots through the roof. The best part....they aren't even done yet and are obviously very active in the games continued development. Hop on board now, this is not one to miss. 4/5 easily, even in it's incomplete state. There is MORE than enough to play here, nothing game breaking going on, they just keep adding more and more awesome stuff!! Well worth the $15!Happy Gaming!!!

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is available as an App for phones and pads. Get it for that to play something when you need to kill time. Odds are your on Steam on a laptop or desktop and want to play a real game. This just doesn't cut it. On the phone its great. On here, its the phone app just bigger with some clouds and some added information screens. Certainly not enough of an upgrade to warrent $14.99.  I'm sorry but seriously, fifteen dollars? I have games I paid less than 5 dollars for that are more involved with better gameplay and graphics than this. Again I can't say it enough, on your phone or pad, yeah this is a great game. I loved it, still play around on it when I'm killing time. But here, it's just not enough.  Basically you have a world map, pick a country or area and start. As the game goes, clouds move some, boats and planes move around the map, and you occasionally pop bubbles. Sometimes you will have popped enough bubbles to evolve your disease, this part is just another couple of screens with a skill tree, oh and a simple animation of your disease, that will change as you evolve it, you rather will grow as you evolve it, no matter what you chose the picture will change the same way. Illusion of choice. Just not a very good illusion. My other issue with this game is the fact that when you start you can only play as bacteria, you have to beat the game on normal with bacteria to unlock the virus, and so on and so forth. So if you bought this game thinking about making some nanovirus from the future...yeah your not going to be doing that for a while. Cause you will have to unlock it and to do that you will have to play as certain things in certain styles. There are only a couple of for sure ways to beat the game with each type so instead of having the freedom to play as you want, to unlock everything you'll have to play very paticular ways. Again the illusion of choice.  Now on the bright side of things, this is EA and the game will have features and things added in later. Thats great, I suggest maybe then you wait to buy it till its released. However, I'd take real close look at the screenshots, what you see is pretty much what you get.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								Do you like feeling like a supervillain? Do you like strategy? Newsticker jokes about banning laughter and Canada annexing Alaska? What about terrible things happening to the human body, all for your amusement? If you answered yes to any of the above, this game may be for you. On a more serious note it's a pretty seriously engaging strategy game that balances actually having to think and plan ahead without being so labyrinthine and convoluted to navigate that it stops being fun. The interface is pretty, but might benefit from some streamlining as actually using it takes some practice (though it's perfectly fine once you do get used to it). The sound direction is also very nice.

content:

Early Access Review
								i really like this game its fun and addictive, it easily absorbed hours of my day, i find the fungus and neurox worm too be a tad easy but still are my favourites, they both have the best control over the plague and makes you feel as if you have more control over it than the rest of the plagues, i do recomend this game however i do have a few nit picks on the game which i will say soon, but first its shining areasGOOD AREAS:1: the map, we all know its hard too put a 3d round object with alot of detail upon a flat surface but the makers in this game in my opinion did well on it, the water and cloud movements added some more immersion it it, so it feels as if oyur looking down upon the earth as your plague spreads. i also like how the plague spreading looked however i will get on that in a sec2: the news, i really liked the funny easter eggs in them,  plus it makes you have a sense of progress during the game with how the news talked about you3: plagues, the variety of plagues is really good but i find the differences lacking and the changes in form, how it spreads across the map is really cool it feels as if the country is festering with the plague, and the whole name your own plague bit is awesome4:traits, i loved how the traits where making the game more interesting upon fast yoiu racked up DNA, transmission symptons and abilities where a hoot too mix and match5:the models and body scales, i thought it was neat on how you could see how your plague was moving threw the human body inside of the plague menu, and the models of the plagues looked spectacular, however6:simulation, this game is a great plague simulator and is a good gameBAD AREAS:1: the models, i know i just praised them but in truth when you add traits too the plague there is only little differences, mostly there are just more and more in the background of the plague, and in the human anatomy area there is very little change but still a nice touch too see how you infect. there is one exception and that is the neurox worm plague you can see it grow on the brain and the tendrils move threw the brain, what i would do is make the other plagues gradually change in appearence threw time. like make the bacteria  grow long or bigger add its own little strings coming of too make it seem more infectous , but again this is just my  opinion im not a critic2:difficulty, if you have a structered strategy the game feels too easy its only really difficult on the first time playing a plague type, my suggestion add a few minor curve balls like them making a nano cirus too counter act against you and you have too make your plague more lethal too beat the nano virus, just and idea it could be horrible one just saying3: street view, in it you get the ability too make a street view you only get still frames and what you can see is a bit disapointing there isnt much in them, my suggestion make them change more often too other ones like showing the people infected walking around or the healthy wearing doctors masks. just a suggestion this isnt a game breaking thing...unlike the next one4: the curser, i dont know if anyone else has had this problem but my curser sometimes doesnt work or doesnt click the rihgt one, how? for examply i had too click four times on a ability ounce just too highlight it, it gets annoying especially when you buy one and arent paying attention and go too buy another and you accidently de-evolve the trait you just got, i was playing nano virus and had nearly killed humanity and went too buy organ failure aaaand i sold coma and got 2 DNA points back and didnt have enough too buy coma back and organ failure5:news, even with how the news makes you feel acomplished, it still repeats it self and has little variety thats just minor though6: the cure, dont get me wrong i love how it works but if you up transmission and the medical resistance tree it just doesnt even matter, half of the time when i upped the med tree so much i forgot about the cure and destroid humanity with it 40% doneeven with all that ive said this game is a wonderful game and i recomend it too any who want too just kill time, its fun some times funny and with the game in early access the game has alot of bugs but there minor and you can just have fun with it. so i recomend this game

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								Ever secretly wished you worked for Umbrella Corporation, spreading despair and disease one bioweapon at a time? Well now you get to live out that sick fantasy, like a true Albert Wesker-in-training! Plague Inc. is rather morbid in its conception, but the gameplay is so fun you often forget that you're in control of ending the world itself. The disease types and modifications are varied and interesting, from a simple parasite to a virus responsible for turning people into zombies-- making for differing challenges each time. It requires a good deal of patience and strategy to make it through. I love the attention to detail in this game, it adds to the realism. The graphics are simple but effective:  Slowing watching a map of the entire earth as it goes from green (healthy), to red (infected), all the way to a grim black (death) is strangely satisfying.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								I LOVE this game. It's even better than it's old iPad equivalent, Plague Inc. I know some people don't like this game, and that's only because they don't like wiping out the entire world population with a deadly disease. There are plenty of plague types to unlock and each has different gameplay which I find genius. The main game where you pick your disease and kill the world is the main part, but they're already working on (and have released some) other assets to the game such as real-world scenarios like smallpox or the Black Death, as well as random scenarios where nobody cares about poor people. They're even working on a multiplayer race mode to see who can kill everyone the fastest. 10/10. Keep up the good work!

								I've been a old supporter of the game ever since the game came out on iOS, and as an Early Release to the game, I can see that NDEMIC Creations have done a brilliant job of creating the game!Firstly the whole game looks so much better compare to the iOS version, giving details about the world, more indepth detail on the viruses and lastly, the polished graphics given to the game. content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
A unique game concept executed perfectly, that eerily shows how close humanity is to Armageddon of the microbial kind.+ Unique game concept of being the "superbug" that kills off humanity. Different kinds of bugs (coming into and venturing into the ficticious and silly) as well as scenario play, Steam Workshop support, and more keep it fresh and interesting throughout.+ Simple, clean art direction and UI that confuses little, and delivers the info when and where you need it.+ Logical game mechanics and concepts keep things easy to learn, yet hard to master especially at the higher difficulties, making it approachable for all, whilst giving the needed challenge for the dedicated. Its even realistic enough that the developers were invited by the Center for Disease Control (yes, THE CDC) to talk about the game and the dangers of superbugs.+ Great soundtrack that covers the emotional gamut of "haunting" to "inevitability of the end", fitting for the game's rather morbid end goal.+ Consistent and solid update pattern from the developers shows that even after their full release, they intend to continue their work on the game from its days of Early Access.================- Highly focused a game this is, it suffers from being not so extensive to mod, even with Steam Workshop support as most people can do is creating unique scenarios that use the game's already-existing mechanics and allowing the creators to play the numbers around to deliver something new.- The game is nothing more than menus and a map, and can surprisingly chug for no reason at odd moments before clearing up. Surprising, given the origins of the original game being from the mobile marketspace.- As with the game being just menus and maps and watching numbers, the sounds as well are functional at best. Soundtrack can be very one-dimensional, other than newer tracks that came with the more esoteric concept bugs in updates.- Gamers who are looking for expansions upon the concept outside of the "zombies" or "mindworm" bugs may not find much more without a major update or two from the devs themselves when they extend what the game can do.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you ever wanted to kill the world with...♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Well then this is the game for you. Choose your plague, evolve it, and watch as humanity gets destroyed and see how it tries to defend itself from their imminent death. Or you could do it the "passive" way and enslave them with a mind controlling worm, which is personally my favorite plague. Or if you're one of those zombie loving people, well we got the plague for you. There is a virus that brings the dead to life. You can decide if you want it to simply destroy humanity with sheer force, or if you want your zombies to become vampires and only drink their blood. You can even bring back the mummified dead. Humanity even nukes the places with zombies in them, United States might even nuke China, or the other way around. I simply recomment this game because it's so much fun to play. I might also add that there is going to be multiplayer and diseases from the past like the black death, smallpox and the swine virus. For those who own the mobile version, this is not some kind of scam. You notice that they put a lot of effort into the game and it even includes new things that the mobile version doesn't have. Thanks for reading and sorry for these "spoilers." Have a good day or night, or at whatever time you're reading this.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								Ever secretly wished you worked for Umbrella Corporation, spreading despair and disease one bioweapon at a time? Well now you get to live out that sick fantasy, like a true Albert Wesker-in-training! Plague Inc. is rather morbid in its conception, but the gameplay is so fun you often forget that you're in control of ending the world itself. The disease types and modifications are varied and interesting, from a simple parasite to a virus responsible for turning people into zombies-- making for differing challenges each time. It requires a good deal of patience and strategy to make it through. I love the attention to detail in this game, it adds to the realism. The graphics are simple but effective:  Slowing watching a map of the entire earth as it goes from green (healthy), to red (infected), all the way to a grim black (death) is strangely satisfying.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you ever wanted to kill the world with...♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Well then this is the game for you. Choose your plague, evolve it, and watch as humanity gets destroyed and see how it tries to defend itself from their imminent death. Or you could do it the "passive" way and enslave them with a mind controlling worm, which is personally my favorite plague. Or if you're one of those zombie loving people, well we got the plague for you. There is a virus that brings the dead to life. You can decide if you want it to simply destroy humanity with sheer force, or if you want your zombies to become vampires and only drink their blood. You can even bring back the mummified dead. Humanity even nukes the places with zombies in them, United States might even nuke China, or the other way around. I simply recomment this game because it's so much fun to play. I might also add that there is going to be multiplayer and diseases from the past like the black death, smallpox and the swine virus. For those who own the mobile version, this is not some kind of scam. You notice that they put a lot of effort into the game and it even includes new things that the mobile version doesn't have. Thanks for reading and sorry for these "spoilers." Have a good day or night, or at whatever time you're reading this.

								I have never been into mobile games but based on friends descriptions of this game as soon as it was released on PC I bought it. In it's current state there is still a lot to do and very enjoyable with tons of strategy planning and decision making that makes you pause the game and go through your options. It's a game that allows you to play the bad guy which is awesome.Pros: Music, humor, interface, graphical style, decision making.Cons: Still in Alpha with a lot of features not yet implemented.Overall: 9/10 would buy again and will continue to play

content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								A fun game, still in development (Early Access). You have to control the evolution of the Plague by spending skill points in detailed skill trees. The type of Plagues available to you get unlocked as you progress through the game, you start with only Bacteria available, you will go on to unlock Virus, Fungus, Parasite, Neurax Worm, Prion, Nano-Virus & Bio Weapon. These different Plague types will have either minor or major variations in the evolutions available to you, making for more interesting gameplay! Each game mode is unique in its own way, the different Plagues all seem to have game mechanics independant of each other. When you beat a level you will unlock different Gene structures, which allow you to get slight boosts or powerups in your future games, these are not needed for the normal difficulty, but can make Brutal or Mega Brutal difficulty go much smoother! There will be more Gene types to come, as this is early access, I have all Gene types unlocked (25/25), but it says that I am only at 83% on Genes unlocked, so we can expect to see more in this department.Overall the gameplay is fun & challenging. I would definitely say this is in the survival genre with a dash of world domination. If you try it out, you may enjoy it!

content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								Plague Inc: EvolvedAll in all, it's not a bad game. The Mobile version caught attention of millions of players when it was released and was a world hit game. Fans enjoyed and loved the game. Why? They had a reason to be. It was an amazing and well developed game. You, the gamer controls a pathogen that infects a person and starts to spread. How your pathogen evolves is based on your choices and how you want it to be. A stealthy pathogen that spreads around slowly and stealthy to destroy the human race or a killing machine that kills everything it touches. The devs made the game even better by adding different kinds of pathogens, all the way from bacteria, all the way to turning humans into friken apes. Now this game was not that hyped because it seemed like plague inc for the computer. Not really different. But they suprised us. The game featured better graphics more scenarios, even a future multiplayer in development. This time they  even brought in a scenerio character for the players. Making the game even better. In conclusion, Plauge inc. Evolved really did, evolve. It brought many different new feautres to the game making the game great with many new options to the player that make them even more superior in the game.

Early Access Review
								Fun, Well developed and the most dynamic infection simulator out.If it looks good to you get it, you will get what you expect and more.If you are looking to destroy the world via a slow and painful death, this game is what you need and more. Originaly only hosting slightly different ways to murder the world with small alterations between disease types, there are now lots of different additions that really stood out to me and showed how good the developer(s) are working on this game. The two recent disease additions of the simian flu and the necroa virus (ZOMBIES) add a large dynamic to the game that not only is fun but shows the great potential for future diseases.I also dabbled in multiplayer which is made to be very competitive and was happily surprised to see how different it was to single player. It really feels like you are against someone instead of just trying to be better than them with out them affecting you.Also:No microtransactions like the phone game... What is it? My birthday?!?On the other side of the spectrum the game can feel repetitive with the vanilla diseases such as virus, bacteria, parasite.For what it is at the moment I give it a 8/10.

Early Access Review
								Who hasn't always wanted to create a plague to destroy humanity? Well, alright to be fair most people haven't. But it is strangely satisfying to do in this game. The depth in each plague is just outstanding and a fun puzzle to solve. What worked in one plague may be your downfall in another. That kind of experience keeps me coming back for more and more, trying to overcome every obstacle laid out. While 14.99 does seem a tad steep for the content you get, the inevitable content makes it worth it and then some. Having put a lot of hours into the Android version and now working my way up on the PC version, it's a must have for anyone who enjoys a good strategy game. It's casual, it's fun, you won't regret it as a purchase. As a bonus, constant patching and content keep this a refreshing game. Just buy it and thank me later.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								Memes infected and killed all of humanity. 10/10 We all knew it was going to happen someday.Theres a lot that can be said about this game but I'm going to keep this short and simple because frankly I think that the overwelming amount of positive reviews speaks for itself. This game is one of those games where graphics mean virtually nothing. The whole point is to create an infectious disease or contagion that infects all of humanity and the kill them. It's absurdly simple sounding but it suprisingly takes a lot of skill in the higher difficulties. In fact this game rewards aggressive players, the only real restriction to playing this way though is balancing out lethality with infectivity since you need to infect faster than you kill.The menu system pre-game is rather nice as it gives you options for pre-game modifiers to make your casual eradication of humanity a little bit easier. In game you have 3 major screens to pay attention to, your primary world map, the evolution screen and the overview. Theres little to no clutter in these screens making them easy to navigate and easy on the eyes. One recomendation I have though is to always make use of the pause time feature. It helps to plan out your next moves but keep in mind your evolution doesn't take effect until after the game is unpaused.All in all I love this gae and am honestly suprised it's still listed as early access since it feels like a finished product. I highly recomend this game, easily worth the $15 price tag.

Posted: June 29, 2016
A unique game concept executed perfectly, that eerily shows how close humanity is to Armageddon of the microbial kind.+ Unique game concept of being the "superbug" that kills off humanity. Different kinds of bugs (coming into and venturing into the ficticious and silly) as well as scenario play, Steam Workshop support, and more keep it fresh and interesting throughout.+ Simple, clean art direction and UI that confuses little, and delivers the info when and where you need it.+ Logical game mechanics and concepts keep things easy to learn, yet hard to master especially at the higher difficulties, making it approachable for all, whilst giving the needed challenge for the dedicated. Its even realistic enough that the developers were invited by the Center for Disease Control (yes, THE CDC) to talk about the game and the dangers of superbugs.+ Great soundtrack that covers the emotional gamut of "haunting" to "inevitability of the end", fitting for the game's rather morbid end goal.+ Consistent and solid update pattern from the developers shows that even after their full release, they intend to continue their work on the game from its days of Early Access.================- Highly focused a game this is, it suffers from being not so extensive to mod, even with Steam Workshop support as most people can do is creating unique scenarios that use the game's already-existing mechanics and allowing the creators to play the numbers around to deliver something new.- The game is nothing more than menus and a map, and can surprisingly chug for no reason at odd moments before clearing up. Surprising, given the origins of the original game being from the mobile marketspace.- As with the game being just menus and maps and watching numbers, the sounds as well are functional at best. Soundtrack can be very one-dimensional, other than newer tracks that came with the more esoteric concept bugs in updates.- Gamers who are looking for expansions upon the concept outside of the "zombies" or "mindworm" bugs may not find much more without a major update or two from the devs themselves when they extend what the game can do.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								I made a bacteria where I made it evolve to make people diarrhea AND vomit at the same time until they die. I just guided the symptoms and stuff. Then I got the notice in game that people were pooping in the streets and throwing up at the same time.There are many other just straight disease types [virus, bacteria, fungus, zombie virus/etc] but also has scenarios where the world is set up a certain way and you are a specific disease made with it's own stuff or just a general one like above. Or you can make your own diseases using the several types as a base.This game is great with each disease having it's own balance to win. With fungus, you need to really focus on spreading right. It doesn't spread like a virus, you have to plan when to do a spore release. Eventually you can evolve it so powerful that the whole world just has spores in the air. But you need to get the evolution points first.. which takes planning. So you can get crazy power but you have to think it through.Many great difficulties each describing exactly how it effects the game.Researchers and other stuff, among other 'enemies' in the game depend on your selection. But always end up starting to make a cure. Oh I'm sorry researchers is it hard to see through the microscope while bleeding out of your eyes? Does the cure become easier to find when you got sick too and now your organs are shutting down? Watch the lab! Don't want to poop all over those samples.Oh wait, no, it's because your whole country is dying and has a few thousand survivors just waiting to die. Good luck getting the lab grant to fund research!Oh and there is a Neurax Worm alien type disease. It is a creature that attaches to the brain stem, and spreads with eggs but you can modify it's evolution do spread and grow other ways. My favorite is to make the infected obsessed with putting eggs in people's food and hijacking planes to fly into countries that tried to shut out the world.Then you can evolve so the Neurax causes them to all enjoy suicide. And another where they worship the worm and start  becoming a religion. If everyone gets infected you win and all humankind now worship the alien things.My favorite though, aside from making zombies that evolve in crazy ways and the millions of ways to enjoy the game...Is when you get a notice that what ever you started as, you had now caused the human race to go extinct.Because it can happen, several diseases rocked human civilization, and the game doesn't let you forget.20/20 would poop and vomit at the same time again. Gotta go now, there is a neighborhood gathering. Some worms that you put on your neck and it's supposed to feel really good. Free caviar too!---update buy the game and buy it for everyone you know

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Plague Inc: Evolved is probably the first game that has made me actually fear for my safety, It's also the first game that allows me to destroy humanity with diseases like "LolCatz" and "Weed" which I had named myself for a small laugh.While the game is in Early Access it seems to be mostly done with only a few things missing such as multiplayer and the tutorial but that doesn't stop it from being a good game with what it has.The game is in Early Access and is based off the popular smartphone app with the same name and well yes you could play that for $2 but you wouldn't have as many Features;Achievements (there's a ton of them) or Visuals since the game looks great on PC. The App is however a good means as to see how the game works, (Game explanation) Basicly you select a type of disease all of which work differently, You then select a starting country to infect your first victim and as your virus spreads/infects;kills ect you gain points which you can then spend to gain upgrades which do a viraty of things from allowing it to infect certain animals to making it more resistant to heat or cold which can effect the outcome and reaction of the world greatly. Your first time playing will probably come as a quick defeat as you learn which upgrades are best at what time in your diseases development and I would love to go into detail about my strategy but this is a review not a guide. :DSo is the game worth the $14.99 price tag in it's current state? The answer is Probably not unless you're a big fan of the smartphone game or a fan of these types of games, The problem with the game in my opinion is that most of the diseases feel the same, They do all have differences but most are so small you barely feel a difference between them which can cause the game to get boring fast. The Zombie and Mindworm Diseases which are new feel very well done providing a fresh new experence due to their completely different upgrades and playstyle from the rest of the diseases and if other diseases were to follow suit and get a redesign to make them all unique from each other I would be much more willing to recommend this game for its price.While I can't fully recommend the game for the price right now I can only hope the game will grow to be worth $14.99 because it is a good game it just needs a little more grabbing power to keep people coming back for more, and although I'm not quite sure how multiplayer will work it could just be the thing to do it. Thanks for reading!

content:
Posted: October 8, 2016
												Is this game worth your time, yes or no? I'm not sure myself. I had some fun with it, but I never played the mobile version. If you did, you're probably better off with that one, since this costs a whopping 15 bucks and doesn't really offer all that much.In PI:E you are a virus or bacterium or whatever you wanna be. Your goal is the eradication of the human race. Sounds like fun and actually is for a short time. The main game consists of several different scenarios from simple viruses, bacteria to mind control worms and "ape flues". In theory this all sounds very interesting and different. In reality though this is where the game just falls off, because every scenario is more or less the same with some minor differences (the Simian Flue is actually the most interesting since you can actually create ape colonies, have them fight and transmit the disease, etc.)The core gameplay, however, stays the same. You pick a starting country (preferably with access to planes and ships) and then click on various bubbles to get "DNA" points with which you can increase the virility, severity and lethality of your plague, as well as develop certain immunities or stronger transmission via birds, insects, air, etc.The problem is you don't really see the effects of these choices. You can mostly just guess what you might need. Let's take Greenland as an example: It's only accessible by boat (potentially birds I guess), is sparsely populated and pretty cold, so it's imho the hardest country to even infect. You need to invest a lot and the costs are constantly rising after each upgrade. ♥♥♥♥ you, Greenland.There's also a lot of RNG involved since your plague can mutate randomly, which can ♥♥♥♥ up your whole plan, leading either to a too quick discovery by doctors or killing people too quickly before everyone can get infected. You can "devolve" these mutations, but that costs DNA points as well...*sigh*.When your plague is discovered you can only hope that you can infect everyone quickly enough since there isn't much you can do to slow down research other than investing in particular traits if you get enough DNA points, which becomes ever harder the longer the game goes on since you mostly get them from infecting new countries. Fascinatingly, once the cure is found, millions of people are healed quasi over night and you lose the game almost instantly.PI:E is not a bad "game", but it's more of a time sink than a real strategy game imho. I can't imagine what playing this on brutal would look like...casual was already annoying enough. Might grab this for a steep discount.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												Plague Inc: Evolved is a well made and enjoyable casual game of strategy with a lot of developer support and expansions, but not recommendable due to the price. On sale price is where the full price should be.As a simulation it has a couple of problems. First the there is the whole human immune system which historically has created far more "cures" to disease than medical science. As a disease percolates in hosts without killing them there should be a rising chance for a natural immune system cure to emerge leaving part of the population immune thus requiring mutation to revitalize its ability to affect hosts who have previously encountered it and will have a leg up on defeating it. Kind of like how the flu comes back every year.The second more nitpicky problem being that the "goal" of any "disease" is to reproduce. Not to destroy its host. Successful diseases become symbiotic with their hosts. This is touched on in a few scenarios in the game, but is generally in opposition to the main goal.The third and most nitpicky issue is with port closings which are the biggest threat to your disease's success and have historically been almost completely useless at stopping the spread of disease.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								I was unsure about buying this game because I didn't know how much it would really add on to the experience of Pandemic/II. However, I have always really enjoyed Pandemic II, so I decided to go for it, because it is my kind of game.Plague Inc. definitely takes the experience to where it deserves to go; the trait trees are a lot more in-depth, and I like the tweaks they've made (the biggest issue isn't necessarily getting the whole world infected, as least as a bacteria, but competing with the cure. Playing as a virus changes this up due to the random mutations, however!) to how those games play out. Severity feels a little finicky but is enjoyable, and it is fantastic how you can still infect a country after its air/sea ports are closed, with the livestock transmission mutations. As for the price tag... I'm still uncertain about it. This game is still early on in development (although there is a lot to it as of now), and the gameplay can be reptitive to a lot of people. It's a must-buy at $5, but at $15, I have to really think about it. IF you REALLY love the gameplay, though (e.g. you're a huge fan of Pandemic II and still enjoy starting a few games up even years after you started playing it), I'd say go for it. Otherwise, wait for a sale, and then DEFINITELY go for it. I look forward to seeing what the devs add, and also playing through the challenges while I wait.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								While some people might consider this game to be too expensive, I strongly disagree. Plague Inc. started as a relatively simple phone app. Now it is evolving into a full-flegded pc-game. It has appealing visuals, a ridiculous amount of replay value and can be quite challenging if you wish it to be. Not to mention the (very) regular updates. And let us not forget that it's an early access game, it'll only get bigger and better. I'd give this game a 9/10 rating, would recommend to my friends.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								The game is worth every penny. Unlike way too many games marked as Early Access this is a full-blown game that is missing a few extra features that will elevate it even higher from the great point it's already at. The well-done simulation and realistic reactions of the world really sets it apart as it's not a no-brainer where you can easily kill everyone.Different plague gives you different opportunities, challenges and adaptability. The most fun is the plagues that are created completely differently in how they work, and seeing how different mutations and evolution stages affect both the virus looks and the way it works is a complete satisfying experience.The introduction of camera feed was an awesome step in my opinion, although I did hope it would have been more than still-pictures of different situations, I still enjoy it. All the different challenges you can undertake also gives it an amazing replayability.Definitely worth a buy. If you're unsure about the price, download the free edition from the app store and you can test it out for yourself. While it's not as fully fledged and doesn't incorporate the features used in the evolved edition, it's still the same game in every aspect.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've played this game for couple of rounds now, and while my plague got cured most of the time, I enjoyed infecting the whole world and watch those red dots spreading all over it.You will need to evolve your plague with different ways, like how it spreads and what kind of symptoms it has, in order to infect the whole world and prevent humanity to create a cure for it.You'll also unlock more plague types, like virus and fungus.This game made me also imagine these situations if they would happen in real life, and I think the developers have achieved something with this; a thought of these plagues happening in real life is pretty damn scary.At the moment, the only somewhat negative thing I can think of is that there are no explanation what some icons mean. Although they are pretty easy to understand from their appearance. This is probably just me nitpicking.For an early access game, I'd say it's a fun game in its current state, at least for short bursts.

content:

Early Access Review
								Is this game worth buying? In my opinion: Yes,here is why:This is an advanced recreation of mobile phone game Plague Inc., which I stopped playing exactly when I bought this game. The game comes with more features than the mobile version, like Versus Multiplayer(recently came out), Scenario Creator, Scenarios from other players as well as sharing your own created ones. Ndemic Creations also plan creating the Co-op multiplayer, which may get interesting... unless you know that you have no friends that play Plague Inc. Evolved...Graphics are much more advanced than in the mobile version, along with 3d zooming in, each country has their own picture.Most of negative reviews which say "Almost every type of disease has almost the same grid" - did they try scenarios? Some of the scenarios have entirely different symptoms, transmissions and abilities, some of them just change the gameplay a bit.This game has no DLC(yet), while on the mobile version, to get Necroa Virus, Neurax Worm, Scenarios, you need to pay some amount.This game is also really informative if you think. Playing as pathogen, which can kill humanity, just like in real game, it evolves, causes damages to the world.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								Plague Inc:Evolved is a strategy game where you control the spread and evolution of a disease (via manipulating the DNA) with the aim of wiping out the Earth's population.If you kill everyone, you win. If they (the human race) cure you, or you run out of living hosts, you lose.The "nastier" your disease gets, the harder the humans will try to develop a cure.There are several different plague types (virus, bacteria, bio-weapon etc), and each has there own quirks. For example , a virus will mutate rapidly (possibly developing to be too nasty before you have infected all that many people), while the Neurax Worm can either kill or enslave the humans.Each game only takes an hour or two, and it's both entertaining and (to a degree) educational. If it has a downside, it's that the strategy for all disease types is broadly the same - you want to infect as many people as possible while trying to limit the "nastiness" of the disease. Once everyone/most of the world are infected, then you can ramp up the lethality.But even with this consideration, the game has a large amount of replayability, as wins unlock new genes for you to customise your disease, and the different plague types each require a somewhat different strategy. Plus there are 4 different difficulty levels to try your hand at.I've got 85 hours so far, and still have plenty to unlock, and many achievements to get (if achievements is your thing).I certainly consider I've got good value for the money.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								I know I haven't played very much of this game, but I'm ADDICTED. This game is awesome. It's creative and well thought. It has an  EXCESSIVE amount of replay value. You get to create and evolve your own disease. Choose from different selections of pathogens, and unlock more as you go! Your goal? infect and then destroy humanity with your pathogen. Other cool features; Co-op mode (future update),  Funny news casts, share your disease and how well it did to facebook or twitter, evolve and devolve certain genes, insert genes before starting the game, amazing community creations found on  the steam workshop, make a country's government fall or make everyone go insane!!!! (etc...)  How ever, there is only one con to me, and that is the price, right now it's $15. I don't think I should have to pay a whole $15 for it, but it's worth it. It's a great strategic game. So have fun relieving stress and killing humanity using a micro-organism!!!!!!!

content:
Posted: November 18, 2016
												I've played Plague since early access, and the devs are without doubt some of the best in the industry. Intuitively, you'd think there are only so many times you can destroy the world with your pathogen of choice in a 10-30 minute rampage, but you'd be wrong just like I was. When I first got the game, there were the standard pathogens to choose from - Bacteria, Virus, Prion - and I'd proceed to destroy the world (Greenland notwithstanding) for 15 minutes at a time in single-player. I played for maybe 4 hours in 15 minute bursts, but soon grew bored. A year on my GF bugged me into installing it on my old laptop so she could play it. I looked over her shoulder and saw she was entrenched in a multiplayer battle, her disease fighting to destroy the world before her competitor's, actively seeking to spend her precious little DNA to sabotage her nemesis' pathogen and strengthen her own. I swiftly took the laptop from her and played for the next 4 hours straight. In my absence, there was now a fully-fledged multiplayer mode - versus or co-op. There were new diseases - Neurax Worm, Simian Flu, Vampires. There were scenarios that forced you into abandoning your tried-and-trusted strategies and finding new ways to kill everyone.I later found out that many of these changes had come long after the early access period was in the rear-view mirror, which brings me back to my original point - the devs are great. After its full release, the devs could have moved on, taken on new projects, made more money, but instead they stayed to ensure Plague became a 40-hour game, not a 4-hour game. The reason you'll see reviews that state the PC version's supremacy over the iOS game is because the iOS version is pretty much the Early Access version, comparable to the one I first alluded to - fun for a while, easy to pick-up-and-play, but not the game you sink hours into - whereas the devs continue to work on Plague (Steam version), adding new content and improving gameplay to this day. This is the only game I've ever bought twice - I bought my GF it so we could play together. I don't recommend doing the same, or if you do avoid Versus mode, because it caused several considerable arguments when one of us did something underhanded to expediate our annihilation of the free world at the others expense. Stick to Co-op.This game has my highest recommendation. I believe it is one of the most content-rich games available (considering its price) and, given a reasonable chance, could be enjoyed by nearly anyone with a Steam account.

content:

Early Access Review
								I've played this game for couple of rounds now, and while my plague got cured most of the time, I enjoyed infecting the whole world and watch those red dots spreading all over it.You will need to evolve your plague with different ways, like how it spreads and what kind of symptoms it has, in order to infect the whole world and prevent humanity to create a cure for it.You'll also unlock more plague types, like virus and fungus.This game made me also imagine these situations if they would happen in real life, and I think the developers have achieved something with this; a thought of these plagues happening in real life is pretty damn scary.At the moment, the only somewhat negative thing I can think of is that there are no explanation what some icons mean. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is fun, It has a certain, Replay value to it, even if it can get tiring at times. I am into diseases, and such like that, This game let's you create your own disease type, and then wreck havoc in the world, upgrading, evolving, and hopefully, wiping out humanity. That's right, you are on the "Bad guys" side, which I enjoy greatly. One thing I must point out before I go over gameplay, is how fantastic the soundtrack is. It's so good, that I listen to it outside the game at times, due to how fitting it is. It really captures the disease feel, and the no hope feeling you are trying to create. This is a strategy simulation. So you have to use your mind to play the game, So, if you are not a fan of games such as this, then you might want to just sit this aside. I am going to go over the main game first, the other features will be reviewed later. When you select main game, you get to choose your plague type, There are a good variety, and you can unlock other plagues by beating the game with others on normal or higher difficulty. When you finally choose your plague, you can choose what genes you want, that will help your playstyle depending on what genes you pick. You of course, have to unlock the genes by playing the game and beating it. After you do that, You are put in a world view, and you can see the entire earth, and then you choose where to start. After that point, you evolve, and eventually, if done right, kill everyone. That's the basic game, it's simple, but fun. However, there is an issue with this, That is, it becomes EXTREMELY repeatitive... But this can be fixed HOPEFULLY by the inclusion of the workshop. allowing people to create their own scenarios. and the developers did that knowing that problem, which shows that they look over this game, to make it fun.There are other game modes, besides the main game, such as, speed run, and custom scenarios as mentioned before. This expands the lively hood of the game, making it last longer for you. And the challenge of beating all plagues on the highest difficulty, is irresistable. All and all, this little game is well made, It's simple, but fun, and very addicting at times. However, That is my opinion. If you like games that make you think, and you are tired of the "Norm", this game might be worth your money. Just to play around in.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Have you ever wanted to destroy human-kind with a deadly virus? well, now you can!That cheesy start line aside, Plague Inc: Evolved is by far an addicting game. If you enjoyed the flash game Pandemic then I have no doubt in my mind that you will love this addicting little number. Now, If you're not familiar with the game, you basically choose a disease and plot to infect humanity with various transmissions and abilities.It takes something so tragic and to be quite frank, utterly horrible disasters and makes it enjoyable to figure out your plagues strength and weaknesses and in effect destroy the world as quickly as possible without being cured. All that being said, it does teach how dangerous and quickly one tiny little bug can spread if gone undetected or if you go for the quick kill route, even dead bodies can be infectious which is where the danger really amplifies.I hate to drop the educational word as it tends to make games lose their appeal to some, but it really is without you even noticing. Having to tailor make each decision of evolving certain things to make it more lethal, infectious, to be harder to cure or to be hardier in cold environments etc. It gives you a sense of how they work as well as perhaps opening a different pathway for said virus. Given it may not be 100% accurate, it's still a good perception of it.Within the main game you begin playing as the starter bug; bacteria. The most common thing and the easier one to beat to then unlock more complex virus's, and then in the next selection, extra add on's such as a start game bonus of DNA points and such. You can make it to suit your own play-style once you learn how the game works, which makes it so much more appealing.Now, from a completely different viewpoint, it can be seen that you're commanding these viruses to in simple, destroy everything. Which in itself is a fun stress reliever.With the recent update of it being added to Steam Workshop, you are able to make some amazing scenarios as well as download some incredibly done ones from other people, just that expands the game so, so much.Not to repeat myself, but it does again add onto my constant point of how Steam Greenlight brings out a lot of talent that may generally get overlooked. With most of these games, the active development is incredible, so much work goes into keeping these games updated and bug free, especially this one. Also getting involved in making Christmas events are a nice sign of things to come for catered game modes and what not for different life events, I for one, love that. It gives the game character in the sense that it's basically involved in current events.To conclude, this is an amazing game that I would recommend wholeheartedly, it's one that keeps on giving and deserves all the support possible.

								Very well made game, initially I thought this was Pandemic 2: Give us Money Edition but it's a lot more than that. The custom scenario thing is quite promising and I hope a lot of good comes out of it.The difficulty is well done, not too frustrating but challenging enough to where there is a decent level of strategy to it. I also like the various game-changing virus types that change the goals in unique ways.That said, I don't really think that the game is worth $16.99. It's not fun or addicting enough that you'll want to play it more than maybe once or twice a week. I still recommend the game, just wait for a sale if you REALLY want it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30
												Hidy hidy,It's a fairly simple game, but some of the scenario's are complex-enough in nature that you can't just start this and then let it run like clicker games ("Time Clickers", "Clicker Hero", etc.) A large reason for that is because you have to click to earn your consumable points ("DNA Points") to evolve your pathogen and, you know, play like you're God with a magnifying glass and the population of Earth are ants.Dislikes (first, since few):My only TRUE dislike is how there's not a tutorial for some things. For example, Zombies aren't too difficult, but the vampirism plague took me a while to figure out (if you're like me and try to figure it out on your own. Otherwise, Youtube has got many "Let's Play" and tutorial videos that explain things as others have figured out.) The tutorial/how-to option in the game has the basic information, but not much detail other than enough to get you started.Likes:You'll singlehandedly be responsible for ending life on Earth. No pressure. It's not like you'll have nightmares over the horrors you'll unleash upon the populace.There's a wonderful learning curve, even if a little steep for some pathogens (I still haven't beat vampirism.)As you beat normal and hard difficulties, you'll earn modifiers to help your plague along at the start of the game, which makes planning things ahead a bit more fun.I've not played the custom scenario aspect of the PC-version of the game. To be honest, I had this on my phone for a good deal longer than from the computer. That said, I've seen some general negative comments about it, mostly in bugs and the like, but the overwhelming number of comments appears to love that aspect.For myself, as long as I'm not in the mood for adrenaline and just want to relax and have something to do, this is a good game. 9/10 (About the same sort of fun level for me as Peggle, chess, checkers, etc. Some strategy, and trying to stay ahead of the 'enemy'.)-Paladeus

It is such an interesting game idea; infecting the world and eradicating humanity.I can also guarantee that you will actually LEARN something from this game as did I, from diseases to populations. Plauge Inc. is also an amazing Real Time Strategy (RTS) game, and you can impress your friends with your strategies (and even dominate them in multiplayer!)I definitely recommend this game. So many things you can learn, but there is a point (unfortunately) when you may discover all there is to learn and you beat every disease on the hardest difficulty.Great job, Ndemic Games!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								I was unsure about buying this game because I didn't know how much it would really add on to the experience of Pandemic/II. However, I have always really enjoyed Pandemic II, so I decided to go for it, because it is my kind of game.Plague Inc. definitely takes the experience to where it deserves to go; the trait trees are a lot more in-depth, and I like the tweaks they've made (the biggest issue isn't necessarily getting the whole world infected, as least as a bacteria, but competing with the cure. Playing as a virus changes this up due to the random mutations, however!) to how those games play out. Severity feels a little finicky but is enjoyable, and it is fantastic how you can still infect a country after its air/sea ports are closed, with the livestock transmission mutations. As for the price tag... I'm still uncertain about it. This game is still early on in development (although there is a lot to it as of now), and the gameplay can be reptitive to a lot of people. It's a must-buy at $5, but at $15, I have to really think about it. IF you REALLY love the gameplay, though (e.g. you're a huge fan of Pandemic II and still enjoy starting a few games up even years after you started playing it), I'd say go for it. Otherwise, wait for a sale, and then DEFINITELY go for it. I look forward to seeing what the devs add, and also playing through the challenges while I wait.

								Is this game worth buying? In my opinion: Yes,here is why:This is an advanced recreation of mobile phone game Plague Inc., which I stopped playing exactly when I bought this game. content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								The game certainly has it's moments where I was frustrated at something not working quite how I expected or the AI proving to be a bit harder one game then the other even on the same difficulty.  The interface is clean and easy to navigate.  It was clear each game what I was supposed to do with that virus type with messages at the begining and helpful hints along the way.  For most of the plagues I would have to commend the author for sticking with realism as much as possible.  Given some of these are rather out there, I was surprised how well even a zombie plague stuck to the rules of mutation and containment.There is a lot of replayability in this game, as even after you have beaten it on normal you have two harder difficulties to get through.  Beyond that there are tons of scenarios to play through of famous plagues or just weird "what ifs".  Each plague type has a set of prelaunch mutations you can apply to help you get started or even avoid getting cured.  The cheats are nice for when you want certain elements around but not others.  I personally enjoy giving myself a headstart in my starting country on a brutal (difficulty) game.As I said there are certainly issues.  Some games I'd have no problems infecting the whole world while the next with nothing changed I couldn't get past four countries.  There are differences each game, with weather and economy news effecting the outcomes.  I do enjoy the randomness but I don't feel it should be that random.  I have also run into a severe issue with the zombie defender bases, being able to fend off millions of almost fully upgraded zombies when I show only thirty thousand or so people left alive in the country.Even with the issues, I have enjoyed this game from the day I bought it.  And sending in reports on issues or suggestions is as easy as pushing a button in the game and writing it out.  I have shown my friends how quickly I can wipe out humanity and it makes them truely afraid.  I'm just not sure if they fear the plague or me...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								Fond memories of this as a browser game led me to believe that Madagascar would be the cause of my frustrations. This time it's Greenland that distrust everyone and close their port at the slightest whiff of any symptoms.The game is educational on both the infection spread and the geography of the world. And probably anger management.It's an early access game, but there is still plenty to do. I've not touched the scenarios yet, but the interaction with players on the design is a big plus.With the main game, it feels like the difficulty may be a barrier to some players and that locking content is a bit off putting when you lose your first normal game as you feel like you'll never be able to unlock anything whatsoever. Once you've got a rough strategy going (and playing games on casual unlocks helpful extras) of sneaky sneaky, kill 'em all before they can even think about starting a cure, you'll appreciate the subtle differences of the different plague types. Then will begin to find the game much more enjoyable and will start developing your own favourite techniques, such as, mega hordes of zombies invading the irritating surviving country, nasty symptom combos and mind control.The save function is useful as well, in case something doesn't go quite right or you just want to boot up a 100% infected world and wipe them out in whatever way you see fit. Whilst the world menus seemed useful, I didn't find myself using them much. Maybe they just need a little more polish. Who knows?pros--Lots of features-Steam workshop-Variety -Value for money-Quick to load-Easy to pick up and playCons-App style means it feels like it should be played on a touch screen.-Endless frustration at eagle-eyed researchers

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 18, 2016
												I've played Plague since early access, and the devs are without doubt some of the best in the industry. Intuitively, you'd think there are only so many times you can destroy the world with your pathogen of choice in a 10-30 minute rampage, but you'd be wrong just like I was. When I first got the game, there were the standard pathogens to choose from - Bacteria, Virus, Prion - and I'd proceed to destroy the world (Greenland notwithstanding) for 15 minutes at a time in single-player. I played for maybe 4 hours in 15 minute bursts, but soon grew bored. A year on my GF bugged me into installing it on my old laptop so she could play it. I looked over her shoulder and saw she was entrenched in a multiplayer battle, her disease fighting to destroy the world before her competitor's, actively seeking to spend her precious little DNA to sabotage her nemesis' pathogen and strengthen her own. I swiftly took the laptop from her and played for the next 4 hours straight. In my absence, there was now a fully-fledged multiplayer mode - versus or co-op. There were new diseases - Neurax Worm, Simian Flu, Vampires. There were scenarios that forced you into abandoning your tried-and-trusted strategies and finding new ways to kill everyone.I later found out that many of these changes had come long after the early access period was in the rear-view mirror, which brings me back to my original point - the devs are great. After its full release, the devs could have moved on, taken on new projects, made more money, but instead they stayed to ensure Plague became a 40-hour game, not a 4-hour game. The reason you'll see reviews that state the PC version's supremacy over the iOS game is because the iOS version is pretty much the Early Access version, comparable to the one I first alluded to - fun for a while, easy to pick-up-and-play, but not the game you sink hours into - whereas the devs continue to work on Plague (Steam version), adding new content and improving gameplay to this day. This is the only game I've ever bought twice - I bought my GF it so we could play together. I don't recommend doing the same, or if you do avoid Versus mode, because it caused several considerable arguments when one of us did something underhanded to expediate our annihilation of the free world at the others expense. Stick to Co-op.This game has my highest recommendation. I believe it is one of the most content-rich games available (considering its price) and, given a reasonable chance, could be enjoyed by nearly anyone with a Steam account.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is fun, It has a certain, Replay value to it, even if it can get tiring at times. I am into diseases, and such like that, This game let's you create your own disease type, and then wreck havoc in the world, upgrading, evolving, and hopefully, wiping out humanity. That's right, you are on the "Bad guys" side, which I enjoy greatly. One thing I must point out before I go over gameplay, is how fantastic the soundtrack is. It's so good, that I listen to it outside the game at times, due to how fitting it is. It really captures the disease feel, and the no hope feeling you are trying to create. This is a strategy simulation. So you have to use your mind to play the game, So, if you are not a fan of games such as this, then you might want to just sit this aside. I am going to go over the main game first, the other features will be reviewed later. When you select main game, you get to choose your plague type, There are a good variety, and you can unlock other plagues by beating the game with others on normal or higher difficulty. When you finally choose your plague, you can choose what genes you want, that will help your playstyle depending on what genes you pick. You of course, have to unlock the genes by playing the game and beating it. After you do that, You are put in a world view, and you can see the entire earth, and then you choose where to start. After that point, you evolve, and eventually, if done right, kill everyone. That's the basic game, it's simple, but fun. However, there is an issue with this, That is, it becomes EXTREMELY repeatitive... But this can be fixed HOPEFULLY by the inclusion of the workshop. allowing people to create their own scenarios. and the developers did that knowing that problem, which shows that they look over this game, to make it fun.There are other game modes, besides the main game, such as, speed run, and custom scenarios as mentioned before. This expands the lively hood of the game, making it last longer for you. And the challenge of beating all plagues on the highest difficulty, is irresistable. All and all, this little game is well made, It's simple, but fun, and very addicting at times. However, That is my opinion. If you like games that make you think, and you are tired of the "Norm", this game might be worth your money. Just to play around in.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Have you ever wanted to destroy human-kind with a deadly virus? well, now you can!That cheesy start line aside, Plague Inc: Evolved is by far an addicting game. If you enjoyed the flash game Pandemic then I have no doubt in my mind that you will love this addicting little number. Now, If you're not familiar with the game, you basically choose a disease and plot to infect humanity with various transmissions and abilities.It takes something so tragic and to be quite frank, utterly horrible disasters and makes it enjoyable to figure out your plagues strength and weaknesses and in effect destroy the world as quickly as possible without being cured. All that being said, it does teach how dangerous and quickly one tiny little bug can spread if gone undetected or if you go for the quick kill route, even dead bodies can be infectious which is where the danger really amplifies.I hate to drop the educational word as it tends to make games lose their appeal to some, but it really is without you even noticing. Having to tailor make each decision of evolving certain things to make it more lethal, infectious, to be harder to cure or to be hardier in cold environments etc. It gives you a sense of how they work as well as perhaps opening a different pathway for said virus. Given it may not be 100% accurate, it's still a good perception of it.Within the main game you begin playing as the starter bug; bacteria. The most common thing and the easier one to beat to then unlock more complex virus's, and then in the next selection, extra add on's such as a start game bonus of DNA points and such. You can make it to suit your own play-style once you learn how the game works, which makes it so much more appealing.Now, from a completely different viewpoint, it can be seen that you're commanding these viruses to in simple, destroy everything. Which in itself is a fun stress reliever.With the recent update of it being added to Steam Workshop, you are able to make some amazing scenarios as well as download some incredibly done ones from other people, just that expands the game so, so much.Not to repeat myself, but it does again add onto my constant point of how Steam Greenlight brings out a lot of talent that may generally get overlooked. With most of these games, the active development is incredible, so much work goes into keeping these games updated and bug free, especially this one. Also getting involved in making Christmas events are a nice sign of things to come for catered game modes and what not for different life events, I for one, love that. It gives the game character in the sense that it's basically involved in current events.To conclude, this is an amazing game that I would recommend wholeheartedly, it's one that keeps on giving and deserves all the support possible.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								The game certainly has it's moments where I was frustrated at something not working quite how I expected or the AI proving to be a bit harder one game then the other even on the same difficulty.  The interface is clean and easy to navigate.  It was clear each game what I was supposed to do with that virus type with messages at the begining and helpful hints along the way.  For most of the plagues I would have to commend the author for sticking with realism as much as possible.  Given some of these are rather out there, I was surprised how well even a zombie plague stuck to the rules of mutation and containment.There is a lot of replayability in this game, as even after you have beaten it on normal you have two harder difficulties to get through.  Beyond that there are tons of scenarios to play through of famous plagues or just weird "what ifs".  Each plague type has a set of prelaunch mutations you can apply to help you get started or even avoid getting cured.  The cheats are nice for when you want certain elements around but not others.  I personally enjoy giving myself a headstart in my starting country on a brutal (difficulty) game.As I said there are certainly issues.  Some games I'd have no problems infecting the whole world while the next with nothing changed I couldn't get past four countries.  There are differences each game, with weather and economy news effecting the outcomes.  I do enjoy the randomness but I don't feel it should be that random.  I have also run into a severe issue with the zombie defender bases, being able to fend off millions of almost fully upgraded zombies when I show only thirty thousand or so people left alive in the country.Even with the issues, I have enjoyed this game from the day I bought it.  And sending in reports on issues or suggestions is as easy as pushing a button in the game and writing it out.  I have shown my friends how quickly I can wipe out humanity and it makes them truely afraid.  I'm just not sure if they fear the plague or me...
