content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Coming from someone who didn't buy the Pandemic version of the game and someone who is into different strategy games, I really enioy this. I feel that you can get enough hours out of the game that the price as it stands now is justified. The way the game is now, without the promised multiplayer, already can give you tens of hours of playing time which is really all I can ask for out of a game like this. Although only a few hours in, I find countless reasons why I should get back on the game instead of doing other things. Only having access to one type of disease from the start encourages you to keep playing in order to unlock the others, among other things like obtaining achievements or even just conquering different difficulty levels and testing different strategies gives the game an incredible amount of replay value. I absolutely dig the simple but sweet design of the game as well. Something about playing on a simple map in HD with good particle effects just is really fun. The menus are very easy to navigate and understand and overall it looks really polished. Some people claim that this game can be boring in the sense that they claim all you are doing is clicking and waiting, but I disagree. Although this game doesn't require as much attention as some other games that I have played, you clearly make strategic decisions throughout your game in order to go about spreading your disease but at the same time trying to keep a low profile so you are not noticed before spreading the entire globe. You are continuously involved by clicking bubbles that appear on the screen for "DNA points" that you use to go about "leveling up" your disease through different transmission methods, abilities, and symptoms. Lastly, I enjoy reading and reacting to some of the random "news" events which may contribute to my playstyle. For example if bird migration was up, I may consider using my DNA points to make transmission with birds more effective among many other things.I suppose I can go on all day with this but i'll just finish with saying that I am excited to check out the multiplayer in the future and finally just see how this game turns out when it is officially released.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								After naming a plague "My Girlfriend" and watching it spread to hundreds of people in the United States before spreading to the UK and France, I'm brought back to fond memories of my girlfriend spreading to hundreds of people in the United States, the UK and France. The realism of this game is unmatched."World of Warcraft" started in the United States and, admittedly, made a detour in Australia before spreading to and taking over Japan and China.Plague Inc: Evolved kidnapped the old Pandemic browser game, tied it to a chair and waterboarded it until it revealed its addicting secrets. They took everything right with the classic and expanded on that content, most notably, many more interesting disease types.I think everybody's favorite right now (though I haven't played to see the zombie plague in action) is the Neurax Worm; it's the one type (again; haven't seen the zombie plague yet) that has its own specific symptoms tree which leads to hilarious conclusions, as well as many more unique properties. I was a bit disappointed in the fact that all of the other plague types have identical symptom trees (you'd expect a complex prion or bio-weapon to attack the body differently than a bacteria or virus), though I'm sure that they plan on creating more variety as the game matures, which is alluded to nicely by the Neurax Worm's tree.People wary about early access: the game has yet to lock up on me, and other than a few display glitches with deaths and infected counts, it runs rather smoothly.If I had to give one good reason to not purchase this game so it doesn't look like I'm hyping it up, I would say it's downfall is its replay value. Of course there's many different ways you can kill the world and ways in which you can choose to infect, but after one or two playthroughs, you can very well have seen and purchased everything. Until you get to the Neurax Worm, and like I said, I would stay optimistic that the other plague types will be updated with specific symptom trees later on.Is it worth $15? No, but is a $7.00 chipotle burrito that's going to leave bloody skid marks on your underwear worth it? No, but you eat the chipotle anyway, cause you're a fatty fat mcfatterson. Just like how you're on Steam and honestly trying to ponder the $15 like an investment banker purchasing futures. It costs like $40.00 to simulate driving a train. It costs $60.00 to shoot those gerd-dern Soviets. It's free to play TF2. The world doesn't make sense. You'll spend a lot more money on dumber things, like drinks for girls who'll never sleep with me. Consider this buying yourself a $15 drink where you can sit back, relax, and exterminate the world with a disease called "Snapchat."

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Coming from someone who didn't buy the Pandemic version of the game and someone who is into different strategy games, I really enioy this. I feel that you can get enough hours out of the game that the price as it stands now is justified. The way the game is now, without the promised multiplayer, already can give you tens of hours of playing time which is really all I can ask for out of a game like this. Although only a few hours in, I find countless reasons why I should get back on the game instead of doing other things. Only having access to one type of disease from the start encourages you to keep playing in order to unlock the others, among other things like obtaining achievements or even just conquering different difficulty levels and testing different strategies gives the game an incredible amount of replay value. I absolutely dig the simple but sweet design of the game as well. Something about playing on a simple map in HD with good particle effects just is really fun. The menus are very easy to navigate and understand and overall it looks really polished. Some people claim that this game can be boring in the sense that they claim all you are doing is clicking and waiting, but I disagree. Although this game doesn't require as much attention as some other games that I have played, you clearly make strategic decisions throughout your game in order to go about spreading your disease but at the same time trying to keep a low profile so you are not noticed before spreading the entire globe. You are continuously involved by clicking bubbles that appear on the screen for "DNA points" that you use to go about "leveling up" your disease through different transmission methods, abilities, and symptoms. Lastly, I enjoy reading and reacting to some of the random "news" events which may contribute to my playstyle. For example if bird migration was up, I may consider using my DNA points to make transmission with birds more effective among many other things.I suppose I can go on all day with this but i'll just finish with saying that I am excited to check out the multiplayer in the future and finally just see how this game turns out when it is officially released.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
												The most morbid RTS I have yet seen. An RTS where you cannot command units. You are a disease. You are fighting against a simulation of disease response by human organizations. Your goal is to kill all humans before being cured. Your methods are choosing Transmision vector, Symptoms, and resistance to climate/drugs/research mutations. The choice of when to mutate how is interesting and fun to experiment with as you interact with the simulated global population. Expect to lose often as you feel out how the game responds to stimuli. Games can be very short, and there's a mild clicker aspect to keep you engaged in what would otherwise be a very hands off game. Pause often to keep up with clicking things and to spend mutation points at precise times.This game's mobile origins show, but its enjoyable enough to spend a few hours on trying to wipe out humanity.

												I've played this for quite some time now, both on Steam and in my mobile devices, and I have to say that I'm surprised as to how Ndemic Creations keeps the game fresh with different plague-archetypes and scenarios -- from the micro-management of the newly developed Shadow Plague to the brain-eating difficulty of the Necroa Virus.The game also boasts a multiplayer mode now and it officially supports scenario mods so if you're getting burned out from beating the game on solo and/or trying to get the unlockable skills, you can compete or ally yourself with people around the world to destroy humanity.I definitely recommend this game for its full price, moreso if it is on sale.

The more people you plague infects, the more evolution points you get to add more aspects to your sickness. And sometimes click the little bubbles on screen. All in all, you can easily see that this game is a port of a mobile game. And while the game is fun you should probably wait for something like 75% or so price drop.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Coming from someone who didn't buy the Pandemic version of the game and someone who is into different strategy games, I really enioy this. I feel that you can get enough hours out of the game that the price as it stands now is justified. The way the game is now, without the promised multiplayer, already can give you tens of hours of playing time which is really all I can ask for out of a game like this. Although only a few hours in, I find countless reasons why I should get back on the game instead of doing other things. Only having access to one type of disease from the start encourages you to keep playing in order to unlock the others, among other things like obtaining achievements or even just conquering different difficulty levels and testing different strategies gives the game an incredible amount of replay value. I absolutely dig the simple but sweet design of the game as well. Something about playing on a simple map in HD with good particle effects just is really fun. The menus are very easy to navigate and understand and overall it looks really polished. Some people claim that this game can be boring in the sense that they claim all you are doing is clicking and waiting, but I disagree. Although this game doesn't require as much attention as some other games that I have played, you clearly make strategic decisions throughout your game in order to go about spreading your disease but at the same time trying to keep a low profile so you are not noticed before spreading the entire globe. You are continuously involved by clicking bubbles that appear on the screen for "DNA points" that you use to go about "leveling up" your disease through different transmission methods, abilities, and symptoms. Lastly, I enjoy reading and reacting to some of the random "news" events which may contribute to my playstyle. For example if bird migration was up, I may consider using my DNA points to make transmission with birds more effective among many other things.I suppose I can go on all day with this but i'll just finish with saying that I am excited to check out the multiplayer in the future and finally just see how this game turns out when it is officially released.

								Thought I'd finally post a review of this. A great game that can be got for cheap these days, and that you can easily spend dozens and dozens of hours on, especially now that the versus is finally out. I've heard people compare it to the mobile version, but that comparison just doesn't hold any water. Long story short, if you like strategy, if you like intriguing scenarios based on both real-life diseases (Small Pox, Black Plague, Swine Flu) and not-so-real-life ones (zombies, brain controlling parasites, Christmas disease XD ) then get this game and prepare to spend (not waste!) a great many hours on this, as I have. =)

								One of the best simulators I have played in a long time. It seems easy at first but its difficulty get's ramped up quickly. It takes time, patience and skill to evolve your simple little disaster into a full blown pandemic. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												If you want to lose buckets of time evolving and chasing secondary objectives and challenges, Plague Inc. Evolved is very unique in that it also teaches you epidemology at the same time, putting you in the driver's seat of a world-threatening pathogen in its quest to spread over and extinguish the breadth of human existence. You can start as contagious but cautiously benign, and then upgrade to a killing level when you have the world under your thumb, or you can come out like gangbusters with immediate killing potential and race against time to wipe out the planet.With constant updates, an incredible mod community, and limitless potential for fun, you'll find yourself stuck playing it again and again just to see how far you can go this time. Whether you enjoy the game for the achievements or you just want some fun way to spend ten minutes, this game is the tops.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2016
												Interesting game!Plague Inc. Evolved is a really sick idea that has the potential to be an interesting strategy game. I'm really not into the bubble clicking thing but this can be removed later in the game: I still feel this may turn off more "serious" strategy gamers with it's free mobile app feel and that really I don't think that it adds anything in terms of game-play: I suspect it's there to add a sense of urgency and to keep the player's attention focused, but I really think that it would be better replaced with something that feels a bit less cheap.That being said, there's clearly a lot of depth here. The game ramps up the difficulty pretty quickly and there are a good few options for altering the core game pretty significantly.I've not felt particularly interested in sustained gameplay: it hasn't totally grabbed me in all honesty. Personally I find that the fact you can play through a single player game in a half hour or less very appealing. I recommend the game on this basis, that it's a good quick strategy fix. I'll be putting more hours into this But it's pretty unique as far as I can tell and it's a worthwhile addition to any strategy gamer's collection.EDIT:I've noted the comments below and edited this review accordingly: further proof that you should probably research something before low-rating. I do stand by my original comment that it still feels like a free-to-play game, albiet it a very nicely presented and polished one. My main gripe was the bubble clicking thing and since that is something you can get around I've changed my recommendation. I still think it needs to be removed for the reasons stated above.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												It's a good game, for a low price, working on any computer and OS (Linux too, thanks dev). You will have to manage the propagation of a virus or a bacterium, trying to infect and kill all mankind, but governement will take mesures to prevent the propagation and will try to find a cure. That's time pursuit, to be faster than cure research.Pros : very addictive at firsts games. Fast and easy play. Good graphics. Full stats per countries. Lots of scenarios (including Rise of Ape and Vampires). True symptoms names and behaviors. Dynamic propagation (birds, ships, planes..., depending of your strategy). Cool game. Cons : after 10 or 20 games, you will find it a bit repetitive, as it's quite a small game. You unlock some bonus, but game remain the same, then you can play in multi-players. Some end game failure with harbors locks are not really realist, and it make then impossible to win. Should be better with deeper biological parameters and choice, there's not so much choices, so it's quite easy, but you can try harder difficulty. Well, for a low price, it's a good game (8 or 9 bucks), more it will be too expensive.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Coming from someone who didn't buy the Pandemic version of the game and someone who is into different strategy games, I really enioy this. I feel that you can get enough hours out of the game that the price as it stands now is justified. The way the game is now, without the promised multiplayer, already can give you tens of hours of playing time which is really all I can ask for out of a game like this. Although only a few hours in, I find countless reasons why I should get back on the game instead of doing other things. Only having access to one type of disease from the start encourages you to keep playing in order to unlock the others, among other things like obtaining achievements or even just conquering different difficulty levels and testing different strategies gives the game an incredible amount of replay value. I absolutely dig the simple but sweet design of the game as well. Something about playing on a simple map in HD with good particle effects just is really fun. The menus are very easy to navigate and understand and overall it looks really polished. Some people claim that this game can be boring in the sense that they claim all you are doing is clicking and waiting, but I disagree. Although this game doesn't require as much attention as some other games that I have played, you clearly make strategic decisions throughout your game in order to go about spreading your disease but at the same time trying to keep a low profile so you are not noticed before spreading the entire globe. You are continuously involved by clicking bubbles that appear on the screen for "DNA points" that you use to go about "leveling up" your disease through different transmission methods, abilities, and symptoms. Lastly, I enjoy reading and reacting to some of the random "news" events which may contribute to my playstyle. For example if bird migration was up, I may consider using my DNA points to make transmission with birds more effective among many other things.I suppose I can go on all day with this but i'll just finish with saying that I am excited to check out the multiplayer in the future and finally just see how this game turns out when it is officially released.

content:
Posted: April 25
												It's a simple game, where you take the role of a microbe and try and wipe out humanity (or enslave it if you happen to be a brain parasite).It is also really quite enjoyable, and there's definitely scope for replayability (you often need to complete it in a certain way as one microbe to unlock another which uses a different approach).I'd recommend picking it up in the sale; you definitly will not be disappointed. Little puzzled why it's spec requirements seem so high for what it is though.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2016
												Well worth it at full price, and an absolute must buy when on sale! Originally designed for touch devices, it works exceptionally well on touch screen notebooks (and because it isn't very resource hungry).Instead of saving humanity from infectious outbreaks, you are the infection and must evolve while the world tries to eradicate you. There is a great deal of gameplay in Plague Inc and it's a very strategic sim. The first few games I lost because my diseases were simply dying off before destroying the world - and not because of human intervention. I thought about it for a few minutes and then realized I was making my disease so lethal early on it was killing off the hosts before it could fully infect the world. So I increased the transmission rate and scaled back the lethality. You have to think like that.There's even multiplayer now! You can name your diseases as well - read some other reviews to see how that turns out.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Very well made game, initially I thought this was Pandemic 2: Give us Money Edition but it's a lot more than that. The custom scenario thing is quite promising and I hope a lot of good comes out of it.The difficulty is well done, not too frustrating but challenging enough to where there is a decent level of strategy to it. I also like the various game-changing virus types that change the goals in unique ways.That said, I don't really think that the game is worth $16.99. It's not fun or addicting enough that you'll want to play it more than maybe once or twice a week. I still recommend the game, just wait for a sale if you REALLY want it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								Plague Inc Evolved allows you to release a virus somewhere on to the earth and spread it to other countries. The virus can do this by itself, with enough time (you will absolutely fail in the end), but you can also evolve it by upgrading several of the many upgrades. For example, you can let birds or other animals and rodents carry the virus to other places and countries, or you can make it less vulnerable to humid environments. The goal is to infect and kill every person on the earth, by all means necessary. And all of this is done in a very realistic way, and it's a blast to play, let me tell you. Still could payless on the IOS but still a great game. 10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								Well, while this game is fun, it has a steep learning curve. I managed to infect the entire world without being lethal, then when I went to lethal, the game didn't throw up many DNA points, which are needed to upgrade your virus, so I wasn't able to upgrade the virus with the ability "Genetic Reshuffling 1" which slows down research for a cure, and sets back said research. By the time it reached 92% completed, I'd only killed about 600 million people. So beware of that.Really though, this is a game that I'd keep on playing, even when everything is unlocked.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								Have you played pandemic 1 or even 2? (and possibly Plague inc)well, you could say that this game 'evolves' upon the others; it features alot more custimisation, diseases and looks much prettier with the 3d models and 'hud'.The way plagues spread is very realistic, and it can both terrify you and excite you as you watch how humanity chokes on their last breath with each enhancement of your plague.*shivers* ahhh, it's that brilliant; but it gets better especially when you get your hands on the 'neurax worm'. oh how amazing it is :'D  Just the way it  'hugs' your brain and manipulates your every move, you can even make humanity think your their God!Zombies: yep, the things that eat your brain, well... used too. Now they just blood thirsty decaying bodies that CLAW AT YOUR FACE! Oh, and hopefully you know that it's a strategy game.Thank you for  reading this 'review' and hopefully you buy the game, it'll really help the developers to make this great game even better!On a side note: it features a planet of the apes disease :D

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								Play God for once in this brilliant strategy game about contagion and extinction.Plague Inc. Evolved sets you, a human being behind the keyboard, in the world of viral outbreaks, bacteriological contagion, and man-made epidemics set from whatever date you start playing all the way to years from now, in which your virus can either destroy or be destroyed.The game offers various scenarios with your choice of different types of plague to choose from. Each plague has a genomic upgrade, unlocked throughout your playtime, which could make your plague superior. After that, it's all about location, location, location. Any country can start this epidemic and every country can be infected, but no country is safe.Currently, as of Aug. 4, 2014(the date of this review), it's under construction to include a few new ways of transmitting diseases, to symptoms that could resemble everyone's favorite apocalypse, to abilities that could hinder the efforts of curing diseases, but that's not all. You will be able to create NEW SCENARIOS in the custom scenarios slot. You can mutate the common cold or make Bedbugs become the prime transmitter of your disease or redo the black plague(even though that's already a scenario in the game) which kills in a month.Overall, the game is not complete, and with current games all for flash, bang, boom, instead of thought provoking gameplay, you won't keep entertained if you're simply a COD fan. However, if you want to play God, doom the earth to suffer the worst plague of mankind, and feel like a villain, then what are you waiting for??? YOU MOTHER, GET UP! COME ON! GET DOWN WITH THE SICKNESS!!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								  I started out playing this game through various free flash gaming sites back in high school and continued playing it on mobile devices well into 2013. This is THE definitive version of Plague Inc. Essentially it simulates the capabilities that a pathogen could have to spread and wipe out the human race. A wide array of infection options await ranging anywhere from the common virus to prions, bioweapons, fungi, and even some more interesting fictional ones like the undead plague, brain-invading worms, and with the most recent update the Simian Flu from the Planet of the Apes movies.  Add to the fact of how addictive this game can be and its totally worth the price.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								---------------------------------------------------------------I ALWAYS WANTED TO BE AN INTERNATIONAL TERRORIST.---------------------------------------------------------------OK seriously, how can something so bad be so much fun? This game is so wrong but at the same time so ♥♥♥♥ing great. TL;DR below.So you have a disease which can be in the form of many things (virus, bacteria, worm, and like 10 more). You choose one form and start a game.You infect one person in a country of your choice. Then you start modifying the disease. So it can spread and kill. Add abilities to increase transmission rates between humans or add strength to the virus so it's harder to eradicate.You can modify it further to slow down the cure research progress. Oh yes, rich countries are working on a cure. You didn't just expect them to sit on their asses and watch did you? Canada, Japan, Germany, ♥♥♥♥ing health fascists send planes around the world to spread cure research.As your disease spreads and kills more people,♥♥♥♥♥♥happens. Borders, sea ports and airports start closing down. Previously issued drug safeguards are removed in the name of a faster research.Martial laws are put in effect. Governments fall, people rage around killing, looting, dying.And all you do is, WATCH.TL;DR:- The game has a high replayability value since there are different game modes and scenarios.- There is stuff to unlock- For some reason I like the soundtrack- I like the sound effects- Simple design- Accurate country populations- Funny news bulletins if you read them- Advance into harder and more interesting game modes- Kill the whole world with disease mutatingThis game is a unique must-have. It should be in everybody's library. It's really fun. It turned even ME, a born humanist, into a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ terrorist.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is my number one Favorite Strategy game out right now. The update this game Brings in so much more Unique stuff and the Mechanics to the game is outstanding. And the Graphics is Great! Ndemic did an Awesome job with everything! The main point of the game is that you are a Pathogen who has to wipe out humanity. Your goal is you have to think about how you are gonna Spread it and kill before they develop a Cure. And for anyone who has played Pandemic 2, this is a game for you. I played Pandemic, so seeing this game caught my eye. All Pathogens do have strengths and weaknesses like for example, Viruses have a Much higher chance to Mutate than any other Pathogen, but it can be detected more easily. The Bacteria can have a Greater chance to surviving in every climate, I didn't see a negative effect there. The Nano virus can spread Extremly fast, but the world Cure starts as soon as you start spreading ( I am still trying to beat it on Brutal ). These examples show how the mechanics for these Pathogens and how different they are from one another.You can also now do real life Scenarios. And they're pretty Cool and Difficult as well. I am still trying to beat the Black Death on normal because when it starts Spreading, they close the Borders off of noninfected Places like Islands and there is no way to spread it to them. But that's not a Way to♥♥♥♥♥♥you off. If that literally happened in real life they would close the Borders. It's a Stimulation.And the Jokes can be funny in the game. One of them says that the new game Plaque inc. Evolved went Viral. Or it says a Guy Sued himself. The jokes can be pretty Funny.And you DONT need a High end Graphics card to run it. Like the Specification says, you can run this thing on Integrated Graphics. And yes you can, just don't turn Anti-aliasing and you will be fine.But I just have to say, if you want a Strategy game where you really need to plan everything, this is a game for you. Ndemic James, Great job on everything. Thank you for making this awesome game. I really enjoy it.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								This Game is quite fun and very addictive. There is a lot of content above and beyond the flash versions and where at first the game play may seem redundantly the same over and over again - it really isn't. The differences from disease to disease are subtle and it is making the subtleties of the game work for you that make this game worth it. These subtleties can make the game very very hard at times.Is it worth $15?  . . . maybe.At first no. It is a simple game without too much flare. However it is the type of game you will pull up when you got some time to spare or when you want you something simple to play. It IS the type of game you will come back to and as such it will be worth the money over time. Especially since it is still being refined and more content will be released.If you can get it on sale (for $10 or less)  it is unquestionably worth the money.

												 Take a moment and imagine that you aren't a Homo saipen. Imagine the damage that their species has caused, the mountains of waste that they produce, the species that they drove to extinction, the species that are reduced below food, stripped of their pride and turned into their playthings. Without a doubt, on this planet, they consider themselves to be the ultimate predator, deluding themselves into thinking that they were made in the image of "God". With extreme prejudice and misanthropy, it is your task to design a "cure" to wipe this filth off of the face of this planet.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								---------------------------------------------------------------I ALWAYS WANTED TO BE AN INTERNATIONAL TERRORIST.---------------------------------------------------------------OK seriously, how can something so bad be so much fun? This game is so wrong but at the same time so ♥♥♥♥ing great. TL;DR below.So you have a disease which can be in the form of many things (virus, bacteria, worm, and like 10 more). You choose one form and start a game.You infect one person in a country of your choice. Then you start modifying the disease. So it can spread and kill. Add abilities to increase transmission rates between humans or add strength to the virus so it's harder to eradicate.You can modify it further to slow down the cure research progress. Oh yes, rich countries are working on a cure. You didn't just expect them to sit on their asses and watch did you? Canada, Japan, Germany, ♥♥♥♥ing health fascists send planes around the world to spread cure research.As your disease spreads and kills more people,♥♥♥♥♥♥happens. Borders, sea ports and airports start closing down. Previously issued drug safeguards are removed in the name of a faster research.Martial laws are put in effect. Governments fall, people rage around killing, looting, dying.And all you do is, WATCH.TL;DR:- The game has a high replayability value since there are different game modes and scenarios.- There is stuff to unlock- For some reason I like the soundtrack- I like the sound effects- Simple design- Accurate country populations- Funny news bulletins if you read them- Advance into harder and more interesting game modes- Kill the whole world with disease mutatingThis game is a unique must-have. It should be in everybody's library. It's really fun. It turned even ME, a born humanist, into a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ terrorist.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								Plague Inc. is disturbingly addictive. Games don't last too long, but the various upgrade trees, virus types, perks, and random events give it a very strong "one more go, and that's it" factor. Some virus types are significantly more fun than others, and there's a few gameplay elements that are more annoying than anything (like how several island countries will close their docks long before the plague gets anywhere near there, adding a frustrating instant loss condition), but overall Plague Inc. is actually pretty fun. A bit expensive for what's effectively a glorified iPhone port, but on sale I would definitely recommend at least giving it a look.Also, you can give your creations hilarious names so that you could kill everyone with love or "humanity" if you're so inclined. So, there's that, too.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Plague inc evolved comes from a genre of games dedicated to real time strategy but on an information bases dealing strictly with graphs and interactive maps.It stems from two free flash games that came out in the early 2000's called Pandemic and Pandemic 2. Plague inc is essentially the same game except presented much better and with far more in depth features that lacked in the flash game.Plague Inc evolved is simple and easy to navigate. This however does not mean the game is at all easy to beat, it is very challenging and unrelenting in handing you defeats for poor strategy choices. This is a good thing. This isn't a menu game you would find on facebook that rewards you endlessly and gives no consequences for neglectful choices and behaviour. A victory in this game is something that is relished and feels authentic as a seal of approval, proving your strategy works. Its also very realistic (in the default state of the disease only) I find it very enjoyable reading the news headlines and seeing how each nation reacted as new studies and new symptoms of the disease surfaced, The visual cues below showing how much chaos you have wrought on a nation is also very satisfyingMy experience in Plague Inc Evolved is a very positive one, I myself have bought this game for a few of my steam friends and they all agree this is a very well made game pointing out the same good qualities that i had mentioned previously. The choices among different plague scenarios and types as well as the ability to tinker the starting genetic make up of your plague can radically change how the game plays out forcing you to adopt a new strategy that was counter productive in a previous version of that same disease.Visuals are good, the music is great and sets the mood of your nafarious goal quite splendidly. It however relies heavily on imagination playing off the description of symptoms and side effects of combined symptoms. Those that aren't great at visualizing things in their mind probably won't enjoy the game. Those who want live action probably won't enjoy the game. For those who do like using their imagination. You will be pleased when you read that your disease has begun making people defecate themselves in public due to diarrhea and insanity spreading the disease much more quickly. The Types of diseases are quite staggering and they continuously add more all the time so its always going to be fun. The only complaint I have on the level of realism is simply the homogeneous properties of a nation, All of the nation is subject to to certain environmental and cultural effects that simply make no sense to me. Sure China does have the biggest cities out there, but that doesn't mean that the whole country resides in urban areas. If they wanted to improve this, they would change the game from nation initial infection to something that illustrated city to city infection as well as how pervasive the desease spreads through water ways, the wildlife and rural communities more realistically. This would make the game eerily more realistic as well as the amount of information at your disposal require true thought processing and strategic planning. Instead of losing simply because Greenland closed its seaport, You would lose because your pathogen had difficulty traversing cold rural areas due to lack of mutation to infect local wildlife. Untill they implement that, I wouldn't call this game perfectI myself find myself sinking an hour into this game each day simply cause most games require a time commitment that sometimes you simply don't wish to spend. This game will bode well with those who are going cross country in their car or on a plane flight or simply killing time as you make up your mind on what you want to do next.I would highly suggest this game to anyone. It is fairly cheap considering how many hours I myself have put into it, and how many more I plan to. It is also a simple game that can be played almost anywhere due to the lack of processing power it requires. If I were to give this game any rating it would 4.4 out of 5

content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								Interesting twist on the "End of the World by virus/plague/disease/etc" genre.  In games like Resident Evil, you (typically) fight against a big organization (Umbrella) who released a disaster. In this game, you ARE that organization, making the perfect organism to wipe out human life on the planet and selecting Case Zero, before a cure can be synthesized.  My first bacteria took just over three years to kill everyone, whereas my virus took just over a year...kinda freaky.  As it is still in its initial build, there are several menu options not yet available, but there is still plenty of fun to be had in the Main Game.  It'll be interesting to see how they develop their multi-player aspect; P1 creates the disease while P2 tries to find it and cure it, or, P1 and P2 BOTH create a disease and whoever wipes out more wins?

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								Already in early access I'm absolutely enjoying this game.Since I've always liked games similar to this like Pandemic 1 & 2 it's hard for me not to love this game too.It has a simple mix of laid back strategy, chance and punny humor.The gameplay starts off by of popping little bubbles, as if it was on a phone, (it originally was), in hope to give you enough points to make some effects on your plague, varying from symptoms to transmissions and "research complexity"... And then you wait (speed time up) and hope you don't get your plague detected before you've spread out at least a little, as your ultimate goal is to end humanity by killing everyone.Of course this comes with variations of diseases and parasites which changes the play style, each with their own advantages or disadvantages which may prove challenging.The addition of pretty graphics are alright, yet it does not enhance the gameplay.The music and atmosphere is sweet and generally just fits with the theme without being uncomfortable.Overall it's pretty solid, but could still use some improvements which seems to be worked on.I'll list a few things I did not like from the time I did this recommendation:Low variation of symptoms: Many diseases and parasites has the same "symptom tree" with the exception of the new Neurax Worm which is unique and absolutely brilliant. Amazing to play with, not so much the others as it is mainly too similar and dull.In-infectible countries: You may be playing the game, having infected the entire world with only one tiny island with closed borders and ports, yet it becomes completely impossible for you to infect the country with most plagues once this happens, immediately deciding that you won't be able to win. Even though, logically it would still be possible for the disease to be carried there, regardless of border control.Common geography: I've noticed a few countries have been fairly detailed in some areas but a bit too vague in other areas by calling them after the biggest country, then overlap the smaller neighboring countries, Yet it would have been more appropriate, for instance "the balkan states" which is absolutely correct, not too vague and not too detailed. While you see Germany overlap five different countries. Instead better naming would had been Southern Europe, Central Europe, Southern Europe, Eastern Europe, Northern Europe, Scandinavia, Britain, Balkan States (even though technically still Eastern europe), etc.The pricing: Having to pay 30% more in Europe and only half price in Russia doesn't seem all that fair. If the pricing had a smaller percentage difference, maybe it would be more attractive globally.Still.. It's a fair game which I consider worth the money in contrast to its entertainment value.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												This was one of those games that looks really promising. A strategy game like Civ with unlimited potential and real time strategy where every move you made would make an impact. That is certainly what Plague Inc evolved tries to be, atleast.After almost 10 hours in this game I've come to the sad realisation that there is very little depth to it. You gain DNA points -the points used to upgrade your disease - overtime as you infect/kill more people, and also from occassionally clicking on little pop up bubbles on screen. You can then use these to add Symptoms to your disease, manners for it to spread and to increase its resistances to certain climates or being cured by the humans. This may seem interesting at first, but once you figure out which upgrades to use the game really has little strategy involved and is more so based on probability and luck. It is also worth mentioning that this game leads you to believe that there is much more content than it actually has, in the main singleplayer, that is. You start off with Bacteria and can see that there are other disease types you can unlock once you beat certain difficultues with Bacteria. Now you may think that these other disease types would have much different gameplay to them, making the game diverse and complex. Wrong! Every disease type is practically the same with a few minor adjustments. To give this game some credit though, it is fun for the first 5-8 hours or so when you don't really understand the game's underlying mechanics. You can sit there and be an evil mastermind, watching humanity crumble before you as you upgrade your plague. Not to mention its hillariously amusing to name your disease after something stupid due to the in-game pop up's you can get.Is it also important to mention that this game does have Steam Workshop, and thus there is a surplus of player content to go through. The player created levels are far more entertaining that the ones the game gives you (and a lot more creative!). If you're buying this expecting a strategy game with the depth of Civ you're going to be disappointed. If your intent with this game is to just have a good time laughing at popups like: "Furries to Eradicate Humanity!" then I would say go ahead and buy this. I just do warn that this game isn't that entertaining after awhile, and I would advise buying it on sale rather than at full price. It's definitely not a "must have" game for your Library.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								It's a quick game if you know how to balance things, and very open ended on how you can work the transmission of the various diseases you can design, if I have any complaints, they're few.One being fungus, it seems silly that it's got such a limitation on it's ability to transmit itself without spending points.  You're basically using that ability to wait for the fungus to not be infecting hard to infect areas to use it.  Second, it doesn't really make sense to limit the ability of the humans to develop a cure based on how many humans are left.  Sure, you might be killing off doctors, but just because there are only , say a billion humans left, that doesn't mean they can't cure the disease any slower just because there are fewer humans left.Other then that, it's really a indepth cool way of learning how diseases can work.

												The online mode is filled with people who just intend to ruin your stats. The single player is completely dominated in less than a few hours. Online mode unlocked everything in a few hours after that no reason to continue playing. Took me 4 days to regret buying a game i wanted since early access. You just click bubble, no strategy involved, game is as mundane as mundane gets. I enjoyed its nature but when multiplayer is completely ruined it has no point in staying in my library.  Think its just another hit and miss title. I would tell anyone this game is 100% a hard DO NOT BUY!!! well unless you like winning against yourself over and over and achieving nothing for it. Then this game is for you. If you think its a real strategy game or simulator it 100% is not. It just look like it should be but falls light years short. been gaming for 30 years and shovelware never shocks me. Alot of potential but i doubt the developer will ever do anything with it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Hypochondriacs REJOICE! Boy this game is just for you. Think you have something Deadly well fill out the symptoms in the game into your own little cup of Germs and found out how quickly you can kill others near and dear to you. OK, seeing as how at the time of this review it’s still under early access, you still can have some fun killing all humans with your own custom cup of Germs.The point of the game is to infect the whole world and kill everyone at any pace you wish to attempt it. Usually I would say as soon as possible, but heck you can decide that by modifying and upgrading your Plague at any time after the starting stage. This game is fun yet simple if you enjoy watching Death occur many different ways with all the news reports saying what Countries are in total anarchy because of your attempt to infect the world.Each time you attempt to play this game and you kill all humans you unlock new different types of DNA to generate for your precious Plague to start with. Is it worth countless hours of fun? Sure, if you enjoy reading the numbers of times you have turn a population into Zombies or poor individuals that get so forgetful they cause a nuclear containment breach at any given time.Most features haven’t been added into the game yet but the basic of building a Germ and sending it out in the world to infect everyone is still up to you. I look forward to the future updates and eventually playing with friends to see how the multi-player works out.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10
												-Assuming you're already familiar with this game-It's a good game, but you should just get it for your smart phone.It's the same game, minus some cosmetic stuff, and pre-set scenarios (mostly created by fans, NOT the dev...who has added nothing worthwhile to the PC release of this game). It's better to just get the same game, but be able to play it wherever you are.-For those NOT already familiar with either version of this game-In essence, this is a strategy game. Your goal is to infect, and kill, everyone in the world. You choose a type of disease (bacteria, virus, nano-virus, prion, fungus, etc.) and choose where you want the infection to start. Outside of the scenarios, each disease starts off the same way: no symptoms, easily controlled by various environments, and low infection rate. Each disease offers it's own unique benefit. As your disease slowly grows from a "patient zero" type thing, to something that more and more people have, you earn DNA points.These points are used to purchase upgrades for your disease; allowing you to indirectly control the effect the disease has on people, and how fast it spreads.The strategy piece of the game can be broken down into 3 catagories, different levels of which cause the world's population to take certain actions.1- Infection. If you upgrade your disease to be particularly infectious, it increases your chance of the world discovering the disease's existance. If your disease doesn't do much, it isn't much of an issue to get discovered. But...2- Severity. Increasing the symptoms of your disease can make it more infectious, causing it to spread quicker. The drawback is these symptoms almost always have some effect on how serious the disease gets taken. Something that only causes sneezing and a rash isn't going to cause too much of a fuss. However, once you start going for the more severe symptoms (such as "Immune Suppression"), people are going to start trying to cure your disease.3- Lethality. The most severe symptoms can cause death, at varying rates. Once your disease starts killing people, the world will take notice. Borders, airlines, and ports can be closed to prevent further spreading. You will also have to race against the clock, as the world closes in on a cure. There are ways to delay, or reduce the progress of, the cure.There are also random world events that have an impact on the game. Too many to list here. A tutorial at the beginning of the game will go more in depth, but this is a good overview of what is going on in the game.Frankly, I've played the hell out of this game (mostly on my phone). I love it, and recommend it. Just don't bother with the PC version, unless you're one of the few people who don't own a smartphone. There's just no other reason to choose this version.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Since it's inception, the content of Plague Inc. Evolved has only increased and its game-play, improved. The game focuses on the "management" of several types of pathogens. Said pathogens are rather varied & offers differing options/methods of playing. The main goal, is to succeed in destroying humanity.As for now, the game is quite active. In terms of development & its community, actually. The game itself differs from the mobile version by a notable degree, with this version being vastly improved in several aspects. Such as graphics, interface, features, and such. The strategic aspect of the game remains as a noteworthy part of the game. Determining the results of one's actions in the game. Towards defeat, or a victorious end. Including one's score as well, may I add.In addition, due to the aforementioned pathogens, the game offers a fine degree of replay value. Even more so with newer additions of diseases, scenarios, competitive/co-op multiplayer, and much more. In essence, this game has much to offer, and in my experience, provides an abundance of fun & contentment.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								Sum up - Good - Expensive - iOS portPlague Inc. is an iOS game around the $5 mark (or your regional equivalent), in saying this a price mark up of $10 is not something that a lot of people may think kindly to but if you do enjoy death simulators or something that involves logical thinking with SOME dynamic game play, pick it up for the $15 or wait for the sale. The game involves evolving a plague (many to choose from) to eradicate the human race. The gameplay is created from number crunching and strategic thinking towards the extinction of the human population. Graphic quality is not great in this title, little is able for customisation but the requirements for the title to run are quite minimum. This is an early access as stated before and buyer should beware of this. Many game states and even options are still under development and only those who want to be involved in the development and social process of the game should buy it pre full release. Features such as multiplayer and scenarios are not completely functioning. There are two tiers of multiplayer in my opinion; the first consists of leaderboards and the social network sharing, the second tier consists of the incomplete multiplayer mode which can only speculate to be a completive mode that heads you against another player in real-time (hopefully). Game play itself is identical to the iOS predecessor; you infect one country to begin with and mutate/evolve the plague to achieve total annihilation of the human race and ultimately winning the game. At the end of the game scoring does occur which allows you a placement on the leaderboards. For more information do check out my Perception check video on this title!

content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Since it's inception, the content of Plague Inc. Evolved has only increased and its game-play, improved. The game focuses on the "management" of several types of pathogens. Said pathogens are rather varied & offers differing options/methods of playing. The main goal, is to succeed in destroying humanity.As for now, the game is quite active. In terms of development & its community, actually. The game itself differs from the mobile version by a notable degree, with this version being vastly improved in several aspects. Such as graphics, interface, features, and such. The strategic aspect of the game remains as a noteworthy part of the game. Determining the results of one's actions in the game. Towards defeat, or a victorious end. Including one's score as well, may I add.In addition, due to the aforementioned pathogens, the game offers a fine degree of replay value. Even more so with newer additions of diseases, scenarios, competitive/co-op multiplayer, and much more. In essence, this game has much to offer, and in my experience, provides an abundance of fun & contentment.

												What can I say about this game that has not already been said? If you love doomsday games on newgrounds then this game is right up your alley. I can't count the times that this game will beat you, we as humans are a persistant bunch, we overcome any obstical that is thrown before us. That is the very core of this game, can you make a virus so powerful, so difficult to cure, that we, the cockroaches of the world, can't win? Trust me when I say that a whopping $15 for a game this amazing is beyond a blessing, not to mention you now have multiplayer and co-op. So dust off your mad scientist lab coats, fire up your petri dishes and get to making the deadliest virus mankind has ever seen.---Adendum----There is also a sick joy to this game when your virus starts to pick up speed and the death toll starts to mount, I found myself laughing like a maniac when I pictured my virus taking down the world.

It just look like it should be but falls light years short. been gaming for 30 years and shovelware never shocks me. Alot of potential but i doubt the developer will ever do anything with it.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
												There are few things more satisfying than infecting the American population with a disease called "Democracy," then guiding its evolution as it spreads across the globe. I was all swole up with patriotism as I watched the American ideology invading every nation on Earth one at a time, blessing the indigenous with the Democratic way and insominous American dream, and killing them all in the process. Just like in real life. And then on one fine evening, a tear was nearly brought to my eye when writ on my screen was "Victory. Democracy has successfully eliminated all life on Earth." Finally, the commies and the terrorists were gone. There was only freedom now.In all seriousness, Plague Inc is an interesting game. It's challenging, more complex than you might imagine, and allows for many choices as you choose the next mutation of your disease, customizing it to the situation at hand in order to, hopefully, exterminate all life on Earth. Before a cure can be developed of course, and before you accidentally cripple your progress, such as through making the disease too lethal, killing the infected before they have a chance to infect the rest of the world. To be completely honest though, I disagree that Plague Inc is worth fifteen dollars. X-COM: Enemy Unknown is thirty dollars, which would imply that Planue Inc thinks itself at least half as good as X-COM. It's not. Command and Conquer Generals Deluxe Edition cost $20 at launch. Plague Inc is certainly not almost as good as CnC:Generals either. It's an interesting game, I like it, but it's not worth fifteen dollars. I'd say a reasonable price for this game is five dollars or less, not fifteen. I recommend Plague Inc, but not at the current price. Wait for a sale.

Why does a government agency have to make a way for humans to survive a zombie apocalypse. Why do humans have to live, who needs them those utterly usless- wait, I'm a human lol. Back to the rating, the necroa virus is a new, fun, and challenging way to end humanity. I really love it, it gave me something to do instead of trying to beat every plague on Brutal. I hope Plague Inc. Evolved will keep on getting better, AND I heard a rumor that Plague Inc. Evolved will be adding 2 new special pathogens, I don't know what they will be, but definitly more unique than the bacteria. This game is FUN and addictive. BRAINS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10
												-Assuming you're already familiar with this game-It's a good game, but you should just get it for your smart phone.It's the same game, minus some cosmetic stuff, and pre-set scenarios (mostly created by fans, NOT the dev...who has added nothing worthwhile to the PC release of this game). It's better to just get the same game, but be able to play it wherever you are.-For those NOT already familiar with either version of this game-In essence, this is a strategy game. Your goal is to infect, and kill, everyone in the world. You choose a type of disease (bacteria, virus, nano-virus, prion, fungus, etc.) and choose where you want the infection to start. Outside of the scenarios, each disease starts off the same way: no symptoms, easily controlled by various environments, and low infection rate. Each disease offers it's own unique benefit. As your disease slowly grows from a "patient zero" type thing, to something that more and more people have, you earn DNA points.These points are used to purchase upgrades for your disease; allowing you to indirectly control the effect the disease has on people, and how fast it spreads.The strategy piece of the game can be broken down into 3 catagories, different levels of which cause the world's population to take certain actions.1- Infection. If you upgrade your disease to be particularly infectious, it increases your chance of the world discovering the disease's existance. If your disease doesn't do much, it isn't much of an issue to get discovered. But...2- Severity. Increasing the symptoms of your disease can make it more infectious, causing it to spread quicker. The drawback is these symptoms almost always have some effect on how serious the disease gets taken. Something that only causes sneezing and a rash isn't going to cause too much of a fuss. However, once you start going for the more severe symptoms (such as "Immune Suppression"), people are going to start trying to cure your disease.3- Lethality. The most severe symptoms can cause death, at varying rates. Once your disease starts killing people, the world will take notice. Borders, airlines, and ports can be closed to prevent further spreading. You will also have to race against the clock, as the world closes in on a cure. There are ways to delay, or reduce the progress of, the cure.There are also random world events that have an impact on the game. Too many to list here. A tutorial at the beginning of the game will go more in depth, but this is a good overview of what is going on in the game.Frankly, I've played the hell out of this game (mostly on my phone). I love it, and recommend it. Just don't bother with the PC version, unless you're one of the few people who don't own a smartphone. There's just no other reason to choose this version.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								Plague Inc: Evolved has taken world domination to a whole new level. Playing on the side of dark humor and diabolical strategy, you decide the fate of the planet, and how that fate will be reached. Not only are there several different disease types to choose from, there are also multiple ways to go about spreading your chosen infection, as well as what that infection will do to the people afflicted. With numerous symptoms to choose from there is no single way for any particular infection to work. Changing your combination of symptom often leads to hilarious combinations, like sneezing combined with diarrhea which leads to "accidents" as the game puts it. Ndemic Creations created a very entertaining game, that I started playing in the app version years ago, and this PC version only enhances the experience. With added features and enhanced graphics, Plague Inc: Evolved is sure to entertain that mad scientist inside each of us.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												Plague Inc. is a very fun simulation game in which user decisions shape how humanity ends. The best part of Plague Inc. is that the user can name their disease anything they want and upgrade it to kill humanity before they complete the cure. Something about having Bananas infect thousands and kill more than the black death brings fun and humour into the game. So here are the things to look forward to while playing this game:- Difficulty levels are very accurate and include Casual, Normal, Brutal, and Mega Brutal- Each plague has special abilities/characteristics which add variety- Genes are unlocked after winning, allowing you to customize your disease for the next game- Start your plague wherever you want and upgrade transmission/symptoms/abilities to your style of play. This leads to having no set way of winning / lots of variety- Straightforward game, but randomly upgrading will NOT win you the game, therefore requiring some skill- You can unlock cheats making the game pretty funny- Many game modes- Very few glitches (sometimes manually saving game freezes)- FAST FORWARD X2 AND X3!!!!!! My favourite feature :)- After the game you can check your disease stats/cure stats and see a replay of your gameCons - You will hate Greenland after this game. Every time you look at a map of the world you will look at Greenland and naturally become enraged. This is only normal.-Also the games take what seems like a long time so don't expect a quick run.Overall I give it a 8/10 as this game provides endless hours of fun, thinking, and stress relief. Great game and I strongly recommend it!

number of helpful: 8 of 16 people (50%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 16
												This is more directed towards the devs but everyone should go ahead and read this. I'm unsure where to place my recommendation. I had fun playing the game but there are many problems that I think the devs should know about and work on to make this game a more pleasurable experience instead of such a frustrating "bang your head against the wall" game.First I'll just say that this game is a great concept and has many interesting prospects and is an interesting perspective on how dangerous viruses and even bacteria can be. Having said that, there is a great deal more that could have been incorperated and perhaps can be incorperated with add ons and updates. Also, the system set up for the game that deals with infection vs. human scientific research needs to be fixed or further developed...Here are my issues with it on a scientific and gaming perspective.1. Scientific research rates compared to the amount of death and mental manipulation that the plague is capable of; They are unrealistic and frustratingly so.Once humanity is aware of the disease and it is infecting everyone, as soon as I start unlocking symptoms that effect the brain, the research seems to pick up faster instead of slowing down, which does not make sense whatsoever. If the entire world is infected and the human brain is directly targeted by the virus (plague) shouldn't research speed slow waaaaay down to a slow crawl as a result, not pick up as if humanity had a sudden spurt of super intellect in desperation? I've made everyone basically incompitent to the point of retardation and somehow, science still keeps cruising by as if nothing happened with only a 10% cut down on research percentage and it crawls right back up in a matter of seconds. This is very frustrating and highly unsatisfying...to be so close to victory and be cut short by an unrealistic program/system...2. Infection rates during multiplayer co-op are painfully slower than they need to be.I can't tell you devs how many times I played the game on multiplayer, cover the rest of the world, lose my co-op partner, have only one country left, have all the transmission abilities, and the last country either dies faster than my disease can infect or my disease is cured before I can infect everyone in that one. last country because the people of that last country somehow have the immune defenses of a fricking God...Yet the rest of the world is infected on a normal level. Just doesn't make any practical sense. How can the last humans on Earth, with no defence against a disease that doesn't replicate in lab conditions, have such a resistance against the, concievably, most infectious disease known to man? Some things like this need to be fixed, otherwise many of us are going to be more frustrated and unsatisfied with the game and disenchanted as I've slowly become.3. There could be more interactivity. More charts and representations of your disease. It would be cool to see the side effects in real time on a 3D model. There are 3d models, but they are boring and uninteresting and are only there for cosmetics.4. Symptoms like sneezing and insomnia should not spread world wide panic like it does in-game.In reality we do nothing to route out the common cold. It is very infectious, causes many symptoms, is everywhere at any given time, but we don't obsessively look for a way to rid of it entirely. Only in the game of Plague Inc. does an infection like the common cold cause mass panic and a world wide search for a cure as if it were cancer...The way humans are in reality: If it isn't killing us at this minute, don't worry about it...(truth). There are some "philosophical" stand points that should perhaps be adressed...There are plenty of strategies and plenty of ways to play the game and I've unlocked all of the diseases, but it is so frustrating to continue playing the game after all of the abilities and diseases are unlocked. There is nothing to push for and I don't want to even open the program anymore in fear that I'll just♥♥♥♥♥♥myself off and I'll have to play a different game. But it does offer a glimpse into the terrifying world of infectious disease and pestilence.It isn't worth $14.00...it's more worth like $9.99 or less and I feel a bit foolish for getting drawn into it. But it is a decent game. I do expect a better quality game so I'm hoping enough of these sort of reviews can get to the devs and push them a little harder to do something about it without also making the game perhaps too easy and maybe I'm giving too harsh of a critique, but I have spoken to many Plague Inc. gamers and my biochemist friend who plays the game and we agree more than disagree about all four of these issues. I'm not saying "make it easier", I'm saying "Fix these little things and the game will be PERFECT" so we can ALL enjoy the game. This is not a difficult game, but there are some "bull crap"-y parts of the system of the game that should be further refined.

Early Access Review
								Take control of a virus, bacteria, or parasite. Infect the planet by piggy backing on public transportation and wildlife. Give your plague it's own personality. I prefer interal hemoraging and dihorea that makes people go insane. Once you have infected the planet give your plague a lemon twist by adding fatal properties such as coma and paralysis. Lastly slow research by killing off the rich countries.Or enslave humanity by creating a parasite that takes control of the hosts brain. Maybe you are old fashion and just want to make a new designer aids. The world is your bio-weapons lab in this epidemic simulator. I would definitely recommand for anyone who enjoys strategy/rts.

content:
Posted: January 13
												"Anyone who is interested in science must give it a try!"God what a joke.Plague is a game where you name a virus "♥♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; so you can giggle at it when it comes up in the news and then click red, orange, and blue bubbles to win. So, your favourite aquarium simulator, but your goal is to kill all human kind. Clicking red and orange bubbles gives you points and you assign them to your virus based on how fast you want it to spread and how fast you want it to kill. Blue bubbles are humans working on a cure, so you click those too to win.This is seriously the entire game as an accurate and complete summary in its entirety. If you win, you repeat the same process with very slightly different mechanics to the upgrade and deployment mechanics, but everything is basically based around a system of control based on clicking some random coloured bubble pop-ups every so often and then, every couple of minutes, making a very basic and obvious upgrade for your disease based off of what its gimmick is today.You don't need a Steam account to play flash games this basic, certainly not or $15.
